revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox document |document_name=Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire |image=Acta Independencia Mexico 1821.jpg |image_width=200px |image_caption=Original copy of the Declaration |date_ratified=September 28, 1821 |location_of_document=[[Archivo General de la Nación (Mexico)|National Archives]] |writer=Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros |signers=33 members of the board and [[Agustín de Iturbide]] |purpose=To declare independence from [[Spanish Empire]] }}
The '''Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire''' ({{lang-es|Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano|links=no}}) is the document by which the [[First Mexican Empire|Mexican Empire]] declared independence from the [[Spanish Empire]]. This founding document of the Mexican nation was drafted in the [[National Palace (Mexico)|National Palace]] in Mexico City on September 28, 1821, by Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros, secretary of the Provisional Governmental Board.
Three copies of the act were executed. One was destroyed in a fire in 1909. The other two copies are in the Museo Historico de Acapulco [[Fort of San Diego|Fuerte de San Diego]] in Acapulco and in the [[Archivo General de la Nación (Mexico)|General Archive of the Nation]] in Mexico City.<ref name="suracapulco.mx">{{cite web |title=Resguardó descendiente de Nicolás Bravo una de tres copias del Acta de Independencia. |url=http://suracapulco.mx/archivos/63767|language=ES|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=March 2018}}</ref>
The document is {{convert|52.9|cm|in|1|sp=us}} wide and {{convert|71.8|cm|in|1|sp=us}} high.<ref>{{cite web |title=Acta de Independencia, sana |url=http://www.inah.gob.mx/boletines/1061-acta-de-independencia-sana |publisher=Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia |accessdate=28 September 2018 |date=24 August 2010}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Generales del Trigarante.jpg|left|200px|thumb|Entry of the [[Army of the Three Guarantees|Trigarante Army]] to [[México City]].]] On September 27, 1821, eleven years and eleven days after the [[Grito de Dolores]], the [[Army of the Three Guarantees]] headed by [[Agustín de Iturbide]] entered Mexico City, concluding the [[Mexican War of Independence]].<ref>{{cite web |title=27 de septiembre de 1821 Consumación de la Independencia. |url=http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/conoce-la-sedena/antecedentes-historicos/sedena/efemerides-del-ejercito-mexicano/septiembre/211-27-de-septiembre-de-1821-consumacion-de-la-independencia |publisher=SEDENA |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930121352/http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/conoce-la-sedena/antecedentes-historicos/sedena/efemerides-del-ejercito-mexicano/septiembre/211-27-de-septiembre-de-1821-consumacion-de-la-independencia |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |df= }}</ref> On September 28, Iturbide installed the Provisional Governing Board, comprising 38 people. The board was chaired by Antonio Pérez Martínez y Robles, and Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros was secretary.<ref>{{cite web |title=Discurso de Agustín de Iturbide al instalar la Junta. |url=http://www.biblioteca.tv/artman2/publish/1821_124/Discurso_de_Agust_n_de_Iturbide_al_instalar_la_Jun_296.shtml |publisher=500 años de México en documentos |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=El Ejército Trigarante toma la capital e instituye la Junta Provisional Gubernativa. |url=http://www.memoriapoliticademexico.org/Efemerides/9/27091821.html |publisher=Memoria Política de México |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref> The board immediately elected the five members of the Regency of the Empire.<ref>{{cite web |title=Proclama de Agustín de Iturbide. |url=http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/fichas/Proclama%20de%20Iturbide%20convoca%20instalacion%20Congreso%20Constituyente.html |publisher=Archivo General de la Nación |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803102530/http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/fichas/Proclama%20de%20Iturbide%20convoca%20instalacion%20Congreso%20Constituyente.html |archivedate=August 3, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
On October 13 of the same year, Ramón Gutiérrez del Mazo, the first political chief of Mexico City, distributed a proclamation with the Declaration of Independence so all the people could read it, especially the courts, governors and military authorities, for them to publish it nationwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bando del Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano...|url=http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/conoce-la-sedena/antecedentes-historicos/sedena/documentos-historicos/octubre/69-13-oct-1821-bando-del-acta-de-independencia-del-imperio-mexicano-mandado-a-publicar-por-la-soberana-junta-provisional-gubernativa-del-28-sep-1821|publisher=SEDENA|accessdate=March 24, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110803231217/http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/conoce-la-sedena/antecedentes-historicos/sedena/documentos-historicos/octubre/69-13-oct-1821-bando-del-acta-de-independencia-del-imperio-mexicano-mandado-a-publicar-por-la-soberana-junta-provisional-gubernativa-del-28-sep-1821|archivedate=August 3, 2011|df=}}</ref>
==Drafting and signing== On the afternoon of September 28, members of the Board met at the [[National Palace (Mexico)|National Palace]] to draft the Declaration of Independence of the newly independent nation. The resulting two documents were drafted in its final form by Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros, Secretary of the Board.<ref>{{cite web |title=PONEN AL ALCANCE DOCUMENTOS DE LA INDEPENDENCIA. |url=http://www.inah.gob.mx/index.php/boletines/245-acervos/5242-ponen-al-alcance-documentos-de-la-independencia |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923185544/http://www.inah.gob.mx/index.php/boletines/245-acervos/5242-ponen-al-alcance-documentos-de-la-independencia |archive-date=September 23, 2011 |dead-url=yes |publisher=Azteca 21 |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The acts were signed by 33 of the 38 members of the Board and Iturbide as President of the Regency of the Empire. [[Juan O'Donojú]], last [[List of viceroys of New Spain|Superior Political Chief of New Spain]], Francisco Severo Maldonado, José Domingo Rus, José Mariano de Almanza and Miguel Sánchez Enciso did not sign the documents, but in the acts was written: ''Place of signature Juan O'Donoju'' and later his signature was added in the printed copies. The signatures of other four members were not added.<ref>{{cite web |title=1821 Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano. |url=http://www.memoriapoliticademexico.org/Textos/1Independencia/1821AII.html |publisher=Memoria Política de México |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref> Juan Jose Espinoza de los Monteros signed twice in each act, once as a member of the Board and the second as secretary, so that the acts contain 35 signatures and the designated to O'Donojú.<ref>{{cite web |title=El Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano... guarda buen estado. |url=http://azteca21.com/n/index.php/news/13075-el-acta-de-independencia-del-imperio-mexicano-suscrita-el-28-de-septiembre-de-1821-guarda-buen-estado |publisher=Azteca 21 |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref> A copy of the act was for the government and one for the board, the last one was later sent to the [[Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)|Chamber of Deputies]].<ref name=Alaman>{{cite book |last=Alamán |first=Lucas |title=Historia de Méjico. Desde los primeros movimientos que prepararon su independencia en el año 1808 hasta la época presente. |pages=259–261}}</ref> None of the former insurgents—such as [[Guadalupe Victoria]], [[Vicente Guerrero]] or [[Nicolás Bravo]]—signed the Declaration of Independence; the reason is unknown but probably because they wanted a [[Republic]] not an [[Empire]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Historia México. |url=https://plus.google.com/111694948348714826308/posts/8yBBb8W8Nbz |publisher=Historia México |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CONFORMACIÓN DE MÉXICO COMO NACIÓN. |url=http://prezi.com/shfg3qbwfrok/conformacion-de-mexico-como-nacion/ |publisher=Prezi |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=El triunvirato de Guadalupe Victoria, Nicolás Bravo y Celestino Negrete. |url=http://www.inehrm.gob.mx/Portal/PtMain.php?pagina=exp-triunvirato-articulo |publisher=INEHRM |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325063942/http://www.inehrm.gob.mx/Portal/PtMain.php?pagina=exp-triunvirato-articulo |archivedate=March 25, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Text of the Declaration==
{{quote|Declaration of the independence of the Mexican Empire, issued by its Sovereign Junta, assembled in the Capital on September 28, 1821.
The Mexican Nation, which for three hundred years had neither had its own will, nor free use of its voice, leaves today the oppression in which it has lived.
The heroic efforts of its sons have been crowned today, and consummated in an eternal and memorable enterprise, which a spirit superior to all admiration and praise, out of love and for the glory of its Country started in Iguala, continued, and brought to fruition, overcoming almost insurmountable obstacles.
Restored then this part of the North to the exercise of all the rights given by the Author of Nature and recognized as unalienable and sacred by the civilized nations of the Earth, in liberty to constitute itself in the manner which best suits its happiness and through representatives who can manifest its will and plans, it begins to make use of such precious gifts and solemnly declares by means of the Supreme Junta of the Empire that it is a Sovereign nation and independent of old Spain with which henceforth it will maintain no other union besides a close friendship in the terms prescribed by the treaties; that it will establish friendly relationships with other powers, executing regarding them whatever declarations the other sovereign nations can execute; that it will constitute itself in accordance to the bases which in the [[Plan of Iguala]] and the [[Treaty of Córdoba]] the First Chief of the Imperial Army of the Three Guarantees wisely established and which it will uphold at all costs and with all sacrifice of the means and lives of its members (if necessary); this solemn declaration, is made in the capital of the Empire on the twenty-eighth of September of the year one thousand eight hundred and twenty-one, first of Mexican Independence.|}}
===Signatories=== The following is the list of the people who signed the Declaration of Independence, the names are written like in the acts. Juan O'Donoju did not sign but his name was written in the acts. Of the 38 members of the Provisional Governmental Board only 34 signed the document (including the aforementioned firm O'Donoju). The signatures of Francisco Severo Maldonado, José Domingo Rus, José Mariano de Almanza and Miguel Sánchez Enciso did not appear to have suffered a possible impairment due to illness.<ref>{{cite web |title=Paleografía |url=http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/paleografias/Acta%20de%20Independencia%20del%20Imperio%20Mexicano.html |publisher=Archivo General de la Nación |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624214133/http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/paleografias/Acta%20de%20Independencia%20del%20Imperio%20Mexicano.html |archivedate=June 24, 2009 |df= }}</ref> {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Agustín de Iturbide]] * [[Antonio Joaquín Pérez Martínez|Antonio Obispo de Puebla]] * [[Juan O'Donojú|Lugar de la firma de O'Donojú]] * [[Manuel de la Bárcena]] * [[Matías Monteagudo]] * [[José Isidro Yáñez|José Yáñez]] * [[Juan Francisco Azcárate y Lezama|Licenciado Juan Francisco Azcárate]] * [[Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros]] * [[José María Fagoaga]] * [[Miguel Guridi y Alcocer|José Miguel Guridi y Alcocer]] * [[Miguel de Cervantes y Velasco|El Marqués de Salvatierra]] * [[Manuel de Heras Soto|El Conde de Casa de Heras y Soto]] * [[Juan Bautista Lobo]] * [[Francisco Manuel Sánchez de Tagle]] * [[Antonio de Gama y Córdoba]] * [[José Manuel Sartorio]] * [[Manuel Velázquez de León]] * [[Manuel Montes Argüelles]] * [[Manuel de la Sota Riva]] * [[José Mariano de Sardaneta y Llorente|El Marqués de San Juan de Rayas]] * [[José Ignacio García Illueca]] * [[José María Bustamante|José María de Bustamante]] * [[José María de Cervantes y Velasco]] * [[Juan Cervantes y Padilla]] * [[José Manuel Velázquez de la Cadena]] * [[Juan Horbegoso|Juan de Horbegoso]] * [[Nicolás Campero]] * [[Pedro José Romero de Terreros|El Conde de Jala y de Regla]] * [[José María Echevers y Valdivieso]] * [[Manuel Martínez Mancilla]] * [[Juan Bautista Raz y Guzmán]] * [[José María Jáuregui|José María de Jáuregui]] * [[José Rafael Suárez Pereda]] * [[Anastasio Bustamante]] * [[Isidro Ignacio de Icaza]] * Juan José Espinosa de los Monteros – Vocal Srio {{div col end}} [[File:Acta de Independencia 3024x4032.jpg|thumb|Mexico's declaration of Independence as an Empire drafted on September 28 1821]]
==History of the Three Original Documents== Three originals of the document were created and signed.<ref name="suracapulco.mx"/><ref name=Alaman/>
===Provisional Governmental Board – 1st Original Declaration=== One copy was given to the Provisional Governmental Board, which was later put on display in the Chamber of Deputies until 1909, when fire destroyed the location.<ref>{{cite web |title=Celebra SEGOB los 187 años de la firma del acta de Independencia |url=http://www.presidencia.gob.mx/2008/09/celebra-segob-los-187-anos-de-la-firma-del-acta-de-independencia/ |publisher=Presidencia de la Republica |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
===Bravo/Ruiz de Velasco – 2nd Original Declaration=== The Ruiz de Velasco family were the original owners for 128 years of the Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano de 1821. This document was passed down through generations from [[Nicolás Bravo]]. On August 22, 1987, [[Pedro Ruiz de Velasco|Pedro Ruiz de Velasco de la Madrid]] gave the document as a gift to [[Mexico]]. <ref> {{cite web|title=Donan al Gobierno de Guerrero el Acta de la Independencia|author=Diaz Clave, Enrique|url=http://www.elnoticieroenlinea.com/?p=17631|publisher=Excelsior – El Periodico de la Vida Nacional|accessdate=October 21, 2017|date=August 19, 2016}}</ref> [[José Francisco Ruiz Massieu]], [[Governor of Guerrero]], accepted this gift and secured this historical document in the Museo Historico de Acapulco [[Fort of San Diego|Fuerte de San Diego]] in Acapulco in the State of Guerrero.<ref name="suracapulco.mx"/>
===Regency of the Empire – 3rd Original Declaration=== A third copy was given to the Regency of the Empire, which remained at the [[National Palace (Mexico)|National Palace]] and was stolen in 1830. Foreign Minister [[Lucas Alamán]] made this reference about the stolen:<ref>{{cite web |title=Acta de Independencia de México. |url=http://www.tepatitlan.gob.mx/gobierno2010-2012/archivo%20Municipal/boletines/Boletin%20no%207%20Acta%20de%20Independencia.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111203005829/http://www.tepatitlan.gob.mx/gobierno2010-2012/archivo%20Municipal/boletines/Boletin%20no%207%20Acta%20de%20Independencia.pdf |archive-date=December 3, 2011 |dead-url=yes |page=1 |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
{{cita|"There is not in the republic another copy (handwritten) that the one in session hall of the Chamber of Deputies, the other was sold by an unfaithful employee to a curious traveler from France."}}
Alamán wanted to get the record during his tenure as [[Secretariat of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|foreign minister]] but failed even when he offered a lot of money for it.
Decades later, the act was acquired by [[Emperor of Mexico|Emperor]] [[Maximilian I of Mexico|Maximilian I]], although it is unknown how and where he got it. The act contains in the back the figure of the ex libris of Maximilian's library. After Maxilian's execution, Agustin Fischer, confessor of the emperor, took the document out of the country.<ref>{{cite web |title=Afirman que el Acta de Independencia guarda buen estado. |url=http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2010/228517/6/afirman-que-el-acta-de-independencia-guarda-buen-estado.htm |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref name="actaespaña">{{cite web |title=Ficha Acta de Independencia del Imperio Mexicano, 1821. |url=http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/fichas/Acta%20de%20Independencia%20Imperio%20Mexicano.html |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215043015/http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/fichas/Acta%20de%20Independencia%20Imperio%20Mexicano.html |archivedate=February 15, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Some time later, the act appeared in Spain in the library of antiquarian Gabriel Sánchez. It is also unknown how he got it, but is a fact that the act has in the back the stamp of the Spanish antiquarian library. Sánchez sold the document to the Mexican historian [[Joaquín García Icazbalceta]], who preserved it and passed it down to his son Luis García Pimentel.<ref name="actaespaña" /><ref>{{cite web |title=Acta de Independencia, manuscrito que da fe del nacimiento de México. |url=http://www.excentricaonline.com/libros/escritores_more.php?id=6968_0_8_0_M |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
Florencio Gavito Bustillo lived in France and there he was contacted by Luis García Pimentel, who offered to sell him the Declaration of Independence. After buying the act for 10 thousand [[Mexican peso|pesos]] he returned to Mexico with the intention of delivering the act to the Mexican government himself, but he died of [[leukemia]] in 1958. Gavito expressed in his will the wish that the act should be delivered to the [[President of Mexico|president]].
The Mexican government sent the document for opinions of authenticity. The opinions were ready on November 14, 1961.
The ceremony to deliver the act was held on November 21 of the same year. Florencio Gavito Jauregui, son of Gavito Bustillo gave the act to the president [[Adolfo López Mateos]]. In the ceremony were also [[Gustavo Díaz Ordaz]], [[Secretariat of the Interior (Mexico)|Secretary of the Interior]] and [[Jaime Torres Bodet]], [[Secretary of Education (Mexico)|Secretary of Education]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Un acta de Independencia fugitiva. |url=http://www.elsiglodetorreon.com.mx/noticia/558409.un-acta-de-independencia-fugitiva.html |publisher=El siglo de Torreón |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Invaluable regalo a México. |url=http://www.yucatan.com.mx/20100920/nota-13/4717-invaluable-regalo-a-mexico.htm |publisher=Diario de Yucatán |accessdate=March 24, 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The act was put on display for a while in [[Chapultepec Castle]] and then it was withdrawn and sent to the General Archive of the Nation.
In 2008, the restoration works on the act began and it was exhibited for a month at the [[Palace of Lecumberri]]. In 2010 it was put on display at the National Palace as part of the celebration of the [[Celebration of Mexican political anniversaries in 2010|bicentennial of the beginning of Mexico's independence]]. The [[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia|National Institute of Anthropology and History]] was concerned about the exposure of the act and recommended not to expose it to more time because it does not have a special system for that.<ref>{{cite web |title=México expone tesoros de 200 años de historia en Palacio Nacional. |url=http://mexico.cnn.com/bicentenario/2010/09/08/mexico-expone-tesoros-de-200-anos-de-historia-en-palacio-nacional |publisher=CNN |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=En riesgo Acta de Independencia: INAH |url=http://www.eluniversal.mx/notas/702670.html |publisher=El Universal |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
The act is protected between two [[wikt:flyleaf|flyleaves]] made with [[Acid-free paper|acid-free]] materials in the vault of the General Archive of the Nation under climate monitoring. Experts of the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] are working on a system of preservation and exhibition of historical documents in order to permanently exhibit the act in the near future.<ref>{{cite web |title=Acta de Independencia, en buen estado: INAH |url=http://www.eluniversal.mx/notas/704114.html |publisher=El Universal |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Diseñan en la UNAM exhibidores para resguardar el Acta de Independencia. |url=http://anuario.upn.mx/index.php/noticias-educativas/noticias-educativas-2010/52-diario-de-yucatan/9189-disenan-en-la-unam-exhibidores-para-resguardar-el-acta-de-independencia-.html |publisher=Universidad Pedagógica Nacional |accessdate=March 24, 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Gallery== {| align=center |<gallery> Image:Acta Mexico parte trasera.jpg|Rear of the act. Image:Dictamen Acta.jpg|Cover of the certificate of authenticity of the act. Image:Acta Camara de Diputados.jpg|Photography of the destroyed act. Image:Bando Acta Mexico.jpg |Proclamation with the text of the act. </gallery> |}
==See also== *[[Act of Independence of Central America]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography==
*[[Vicente Riva Palacio]] (1880) ''México a través de los siglos'' [https://archive.org/stream/mxicotravsde04tomorich#page/12/mode/2up Volume IV: "México Independiente"]. Mexico City, Cumbre.
==External links== {{wikisource|es:Acta de independencia del Imperio Mexicano|objeto=una copia|preposición=del}} * México in documents ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110826094014/http://www.agn.gob.mx/independencia/Imagenes/index1.php?CodigoReferencia=MX09017AGNCL02SB05FO131AICMUS001 Photograph of the original Act of Independence of the Mexican Empire of the Nation's General Archive] * [http://www.biblioteca.tv/artman2/publish/1821_124/Segunda_y_definitiva_Acta_de_Independencia_del_Imp_167.shtml Acta de Independencia del Imperio mexicano]''. 500 años de México en documentos. Consulted on November 4, 2009.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Declaration Of Independence Of The Mexican Empire}} [[Category:Declarations of independence|Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican War of Independence]] [[Category:1821 in Mexico]] [[Category:1821 in New Spain]] [[Category:Colonial Mexico]] [[Category:Independent Mexico]] [[Category:New Spain]] [[Category:Political history of Mexico]] [[Category:September 1821 events]] [[Category:1821 documents]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox website | name = Dictionary.com | logo = Dictionary.com logo.svg | url = {{URL|http://dictionary.com}} | commercial = Yes | type = [[Dictionary]] | language = [[English language|English]] | owner = [[IAC (company)|IAC]] | author = Brian Kariger
Daniel Fierro | launch_date = {{start date and age|1995|5|14}} }} '''Dictionary.com''' is an online dictionary whose domain was first registered on May 14, 1995.[http://whois.domaintools.com/dictionary.com Dictionary.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools] page at DomainTools.com. Retrieved June 16, 2016. The company was founded by Brian Kariger and Daniel Fierro as part of Lexico Publishing, which also started Thesaurus.com and [[Reference.com]].{{cite web|title=Lexico, Dictionary.com Being Acquired By Ask.com; Price In $100 Million Range|url=http://gigaom.com/2008/05/15/419-lexico-dictionarycom-being-acquired-by-askcom-after-100-million-answers/|publisher=Gigacom|accessdate=2014-01-24}} In 2008, Dictionary.com was acquired by [[Ask.com]], an [[IAC (company)|IAC company]]. ==Content== The content for Dictionary.com is based on the ''[[Random House Unabridged Dictionary]]'', with other content from the ''[[Collins English Dictionary]]'', ''[[American Heritage Dictionary]]'' and others.{{cite web|url=http://content.dictionary.com/|title=Dictionary.com - About Us|accessdate=October 8, 2015}} ==Features and apps== On Monday, May 3, 1999, Dictionary.com began its Word of the Day feature.{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/wordoftheday/1999/05/03/emolument|title=emolument - Word of The Day}} In April 2009, Dictionary.com offered their first dictionary [[Mobile app|app]] in the [[iOS]] [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]]. Since then, they have released the Android version, as well as a standalone [[thesaurus]] app called ''Thesaurus Rex'', along with education apps, ''Dictionary.com Flashcards'', ''Word Dynamo'', and ''Learning to Read with Zoo Animals''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://dictionary.reference.com}} {{IAC}} [[Category:Online dictionaries]] [[Category:Thesauri]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1995]] [[Category:IAC (company)]]

page.title: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology

revision.text:
{{Italic title|force=true}} [[File:Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology TITLE.jpg|right|thumb]] The '''''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology''''' (1849, originally published 1844 under a slightly different title) is an [[encyclopedia]]/[[biographical dictionary]]. Edited by [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]], the dictionary spans three volumes and 3,700 pages. It is a classic work of 19th-century [[lexicography]]. The work is a companion to Smith's ''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities]]'' and ''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Geography]]''.{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Smith, Sir William |volume=25 |page=270}} ==Authors and scope== [[File:Philolaus-and-Philomelus-Pythagorean-Book.jpg|thumb|Excerpt from [[Philolaus]] Pythagoras book, (Charles Peter Mason, 1870)]] The work lists thirty-five authors in addition to the editor, who is also an author for some definitions and articles. The authors were [[Classics|classical]] scholars, primarily from [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], [[Rugby School]], and the [[University of Bonn]], but some were from other institutions. Many of the mythological entries were the work of the German expatriate [[Leonhard Schmitz]], who helped to popularise German classical scholarship in Britain.{{cite news |author=[[Nick Lowe (classicist)|Nick Lowe]] |title=Killing the Graves myth |work=[[The Times|Times Online]] |location=London |date=20 December 2005 |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/others/article1888498.ece |accessdate=2016-02-26}} With respect to biographies, Smith intended to be comprehensive. In the preface, he writes:
The biographical articles in this work include the names of all persons of any importance which occur in the Greek and Roman writers, from the earliest times down to the extinction of the Western Empire in the year 476 of our era, and to the extinction of the Eastern Empire by the capture of Constantinople by the turks in the year 1453.
[[Samuel Sharpe (scholar)|Samuel Sharpe]] thought [[Edward Bunbury]] had plagiarised his work, as he wrote of in his diary entry on 3 September 1850:
I certainly felt mortified on reading the articles on the Ptolemies in Dr. Smith's "Dictionary of Classical Biography." They were all written by E. H. Bunbury with the help of my "History of Egypt," and with-out any acknowledgment, though he even borrowed the volume from my brother [[Daniel Sharpe|Dan]] for the purpose.{{cite book|last1=Clayden|first1=PW|title=Samuel Sharpe|page=82|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924026852180/cu31924026852180_djvu.txt|accessdate=10 May 2016}}
Many of the ''Dictionary'''s definitions and articles have been referred to in more recent works, and [[Robert Graves]] has been accused of "lifting his impressive-looking source references straight, and unchecked" from it when writing ''[[The Greek Myths]]''. ==Use and availability today== The work is now in the [[public domain]], and is available in several places on the Internet. While still largely accurate (only rarely have ancient texts been emended so severely as to warrant a biographical change), much is missing, especially more recent discoveries (such as [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Constitution of the Athenians (Aristotle)|Constitution of the Athenians]]'', or the decipherment of [[Linear B]]) and epigraphic material. Perhaps more seriously, the context in which ancient evidence is viewed has often changed in the intervening century and a half. == See also == * ''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities]]'' * ''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Geography]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology}} {{wikisource|Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology|''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology''}} *[http://www.hti.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=moa;idno=ACL3129.0001.001 ''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.'' Vol. I] online at [[University of Michigan]] Library. (Entries: Abaeus – Dysponteus) *[http://www.hti.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=moa;idno=ACL3129.0002.001 ''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.'' Vol. II] online at University of Michigan Library. (Entries: Ea'rinus, Fla'vius – Nyx) *[http://www.hti.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=moa;idno=ACL3129.0003.001 ''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.'' Vol. III] online at University of Michigan Library. (Entries: Oarses – Zygia and Zygius) Also the [[Internet Archive]] has a derivative work: *{{cite book|last=Smith |first=William |year=1853|title=A new classical dictionary of biography, mythology, and geography, partly based on the "Dictionary of Greek and Roman biography and mythology."|location=London |publisher=Murray |url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924091208342}} *{{cite book|last=Anthon |first=Charles |last2=Smith |first2=William|year=1860|title=A new classical dictionary of Greek and Roman biography, mythology and geography: partly based upon the Dictionary of Greek and Roman biography and mythology by William Smith (1860)|location=New York |publisher=Harper and Brothers |url=https://archive.org/details/newclassicaldict00anthiala}} {{Authority control}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1849 books]] [[Category:Biographical dictionaries by topic|Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] [[Category:Reference works in the public domain]] [[Category:References on Greek mythology]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2) ([[User:Iggy the Swan|Iggy the Swan]])
revision.text:
{{refimprove |date=August 2009}}<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Fernandel Don Camillo.jpg|thumb|[[Fernandel]] as Don Camillo]] --> [[File:Brescello statua don Camillo 2008.jpg|thumb|Don Camillo statue in [[Brescello]]]] '''Don Camillo''' {{IPA-it|ˈdɔŋ kaˈmillo|}} is a character created by the Italian writer and journalist [[Giovannino Guareschi]], whose name, and some of his character, is based on an actual [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] priest, [[World War II]] partisan and detainee at the concentration camps of [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]] and [[Mauthausen concentration camp|Mauthausen]], named Don Camillo Valota (1912–1998).<ref>{{Citation |url= http://www.mkoe.at/ | title= Mauthausen Komitee Österreich |trans-title= Austrian Mauthausen Committee | language= de}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation |url= http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1998/novembre/05/Morto_Bormio_don_Camillo_suo_co_5_9811051913.shtml |title= Morto a Bormio don Camillo; Il suo nome ispiro' Guareschi | language= Italian |trans-title=Dead at Bormio don Camillo; his name inspired Guareschi |newspaper= [[Corriere della Sera]] |date= 5 November 1998}}.</ref> Guareschi was also inspired by Don Alessandro Parenti, a priest of [[Trepalle]], near the Swiss border. The fictional Don Camillo is one of two main protagonists of Guareschi's short stories, the other being the communist mayor of the town, Peppone. The stories are set in what Guareschi refers to as the "small world" of rural Italy after World War II.
Most of the Don Camillo stories came out in the weekly magazine ''Candido'', founded by Guareschi with Giovanni Mosca. These "Little World" (Italian: ''Mondo piccolo'') stories amounted to 347 in total and were put together and published in eight books, only the first three of which were published when Guareschi was still alive.
==Characterisation== [[File:Don camillo4.jpg|thumb|Don Camillo played by [[Fernandel]]]] In the post-war years (after 1945), [[Don (honorific)|Don]] '''Camillo Tarocci''' (his full name, which he rarely uses) is the hotheaded priest of a small town in the [[Po valley]] in northern [[Italy]]. Don Camillo is a big man, tall and strong with hard fists. For the films, the town chosen to represent that of the books was [[Brescello]] (which currently has a museum dedicated to Don Camillo and Peppone) after the production of movies based on Guareschi's tales, but in the first story Don Camillo is introduced as the parish priest of Ponteratto. [[File:Don camillo.jpg|thumb|Don Camillo talking with [[Jesus]]]]
Don Camillo is constantly at odds with the [[communist]] mayor, Giuseppe Bottazzi, better known as '''Peppone''' (meaning, roughly, ''Big Joe'') and is also on very close terms with the [[crucifix]] in his town church. Through the crucifix he hears the voice of Christ.<ref name = lower-alpha>As the author notes in the preface of the first book, not the Christ, but "his" Christ, the voice of his conscience.</ref> The Christ in the crucifix often has far greater understanding than Don Camillo of the troubles of the people, and has to constantly but gently reprimand the priest for his impatience.
What Peppone and Camillo have in common is an interest in the well-being of the town. They also appear to have both been [[Italian Resistance Movement|partisan]] fighters during [[World War II]]; one episode mentions Camillo having braved German patrols in order to reach Peppone and his fellow Communists in the mountains and administer Mass to them under field conditions. While Peppone makes public speeches about how "the reactionaries" ought to be shot, and Don Camillo preaches [[fire and brimstone]] against "godless Communists", they actually grudgingly admire each other. Therefore, they sometimes end up working together in peculiar circumstances, though keeping up their squabbling. Thus, although he publicly opposes the Church as a Party duty, Peppone takes his gang to the church and baptises his children there, which makes him part of Don Camillo's flock; also, Peppone and other Communists are seen as sharing in veneration of the [[Virgin Mary]] and local Saints. Don Camillo also never condemns Peppone himself, but the ideology of communism which is in direct opposition to the church.
As depicted in the stories, the Communists are the only political party with a mass grassroots organization in the town. The [[Italian Christian Democratic Party]], the main force in Italian politics at the time, does not have a local political organization (at least, none is ever mentioned); rather, it is the Catholic Church which unofficially but very obviously plays that role. Don Camillo thus plays an explicitly political as well as religious role. For example, when the Communists organize a local campaign to sign the [[Stockholm Peace Appeal]], it is Don Camillo who organizes a counter-campaign, and townspeople take for granted that such a political campaign is part of his work as priest.
Many stories are satirical and take on the real world political divide between the Italian [[Roman Catholic Church]] and the [[Italian Communist Party]], not to mention other worldly politics. Others are tragedies about schism, politically motivated murder, and personal [[Feud|vendetta]]s in a small town where everyone knows everyone else, but not everyone necessarily likes everyone else very much.
Political forces other than the Communists and the Catholics have only a marginal presence. In one episode the local Communists are incensed at the announcement that the small [[Italian Liberal Party]] has scheduled an elections rally in their town, and mobilize in force to break it up — only to discover virtually no local Liberals have turned up; the Liberal speaker, a middle-aged professor, speaks to a predominantly Communist audience and wins its grudging respect by his courage and determination.
In one story, Don Camillo visits the [[Soviet Union]], pretending to be a [[comrade]]. In another, the arrival of pop culture and motorcycles propels Don Camillo into fighting "decadence", a struggle in which he finds he has his hands full, especially when the Christ mainly smiles benevolently on the young rascals. In this later collection, Peppone is the proprietor of several profitable dealerships, riding the "Boom" years of the 1960s in Italy. He is no longer quite the committed Communist he once was, but he still does not get on with Don Camillo — at least not in public. Don Camillo has his own problems — the [[Second Vatican Council]] has brought changes in the Church, and a new assistant priest, who comes to be called Don Chichì, has been foisted upon him to see that Don Camillo moves with the times. Don Camillo, of course, has other ideas.
Despite their bickering, the goodness and generosity of each character can be seen during hard times. They always understand and respect each other when one is in danger, when a flood devastates the town, when death takes a loved one, and in many other situations in which the two "political enemies" show their mutual respect for one another and fight side by side for the same ideals (even if they are each conditioned by their individual public roles in society).
Guareschi created a second series of novels about a similar character, Don Candido, Archbishop of Trebilie (or Trebiglie, literally "three marble balls" or "three billiard balls"). The name of this fictional town is a play on words of [[Trepalle]] (literally "three balls"), a real town (near [[Livigno]]) whose priest was an acquaintance of Guareschi's.
== Books in chronological order == The following Italian language books have been published: * ''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo''. [Pub: Rizzoli, 1948] Literally: ''Little World: Don Camillo'' * ''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e il suo gregge''. [Pub: Rizzoli, 1953] Literally: ''Little World: Don Camillo and His Flock'' * ''Mondo Piccolo: Il compagno don Camillo''. [Pub: Rizzoli, 1963] Literally: ''Little World: Comrade Don Camillo''
The following Italian language books have been published posthumously: * ''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi''. [Pub: Rizzoli, 1969] Literally: ''Little World: Don Camillo and the Youth of Today'' * ''Gente così''. 1980. * ''Lo spumarino pallido''. 1981. * ''Noi del Boscaccio''. 1983. * ''L'anno di don Camillo''. 1986. * ''Il decimo clandestino''. 1987. * ''Ciao don Camillo''. 1996. * ''Don Camillo e don Chichì''. 1996. The complete version of ''Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi'' * ''Don Camillo e Peppone''. [Pub: Rizzoli, 2007] {{ISBN|978-88-486-0355-3}}
The following US English translations have been published: * ''The Little World of Don Camillo''. [Pub: Pellegrini and Cudahy, 1950] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo'', translated by Una Vincenzo Troubridge.) * ''Don Camillo and His Flock''. [Pub: Pellegrini and Cudahy, 1952] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e il suo gregge'', translated by [[Frances Frenaye]].) * ''Don Camillo's Dilemma''. [Pub: Farrar, Straus, and Young, Inc., 1954] (Collection of stories for English publication, translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Don Camillo takes the Devil by the Tail''. [Pub: Farrar, Straus, and Young, Inc., 1957] (Collection of stories for English publication, translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Comrade Don Camillo''. [Pub: Farrar, Straus, and Giroux, Inc., 1964] (''Mondo Piccolo: Il compagno don Camillo'', translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Don Camillo Meets the Flower Children''. [Pub: Farrar, Straus, and Giroux, Inc., 1970] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi'', translated by L.K. Conrad.)
The following UK English translations have been published: * ''The Little World of Don Camillo''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1951] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo'', translated by Una Vincenzo Troubridge.) * ''Don Camillo and the Prodigal Son''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1952] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e il suo gregge'', translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Don Camillo's Dilemma''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1954] (Collection of stories for English publication, translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Don Camillo and the Devil''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1957] (Collection of stories for English publication, translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Comrade Don Camillo''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1964] (''Mondo Piccolo: Il compagno don Camillo'', translated by Frances Frenaye.) * ''Don Camillo Meets Hell's Angels''. [Pub: Victor Gollancz Ltd, 1970] (''Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi'', translated by L.K. Conrad.) * "The Complete Little World of Don Camillo" [Pub. Pilot Productions, 2013] ('Mondo Piccolo: Don Camillo'', translated by Adam Elgar) * "Don Camillo and His Flock" [Pub. Pilot Productions, 2015] ('Don Camillo e il duo gregge'', translated by Lucinda Byatt, Theresa Federici, Frances Frenaye, Wendell Ricketts)
The following five were compiled into a larger book published in 1980: ''The World of Don Camillo'',<ref name=UKbook>The World of don Camillo, Giovanni Guareschi, pub 1980 Victor Gollancz Ltd; {{ISBN|0-575-02933-1}}</ref> to coincide with the television adaptation:
* ''The Little World of Don Camillo''. * ''Don Camillo and the Prodigal Son''. * ''Don Camillo's Dilemma''. * ''Don Camillo and the Devil''. * ''Comrade Don Camillo''.
''The World of Don Camillo'' does not contain all the stories contained in the individual books. The Italian, US English and UK English publications often have a different number of stories within them.
==Adaptations==
===Films=== A series of black-and-white films were made between 1952 and 1965. These were French-Italian coproductions and were simultaneously released in both languages. Don Camillo was played by French actor [[Fernandel]], Peppone by the Italian actor [[Gino Cervi]], quite a Guareschi-lookalike, both tall and bulky with big mustaches. The author of the original stories was involved in the scripts and helped select the main actors. To this day, the films are screened in Europe. The titles were:
*''[[Le Petit Monde de Don Camillo|The Little World of Don Camillo]]'' (Italian: ''Don Camillo''; French: ''Le Petit Monde de don Camillo'')<ref>{{IMDb title|0043918|Don Camillo (1952)}}</ref> *''[[The Return of Don Camillo]]'' (Italian:'' Il ritorno di don Camillo ''; French: ''Le Retour de don Camillo'')<ref>{{IMDb title|0045081|Le retour de Don Camillo}}</ref> *''[[Don Camillo's Last Round]]'' (Italian: ''Don Camillo e l'onorevole Peppone''; French: ''La Grande Bagarre'')<ref>{{IMDb title|0048002|Don Camillo e l'on. Peppone}}</ref> *''[[Don Camillo: Monsignor]]'' (Italian: ''Don Camillo monsignore ma non troppo''; French:'' Don Camillo Monseigneur'')<ref>{{IMDb title|0054814|Don Camillo monsignore ma non troppo}}</ref> *''[[Don Camillo in Moscow]]'' (Italian: ''Il compagno don Camillo''; French:'' Don Camillo en Russie'')<ref>{{IMDb title|0059049|Il compagno Don Camillo}}</ref>
Mario Camerini began filming the French-Italian film ''Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi''<ref>{{IMDb title|0068495|Don Camillo e i giovani d'oggi}}</ref> but had to stop filming due to Fernandel's falling ill, which resulted in his untimely death. The film was then completed in 1972 with [[Gastone Moschin]] playing the role of Don Camillo and [[Lionel Stander]] as Peppone. A Don Camillo (''[[The World of Don Camillo]]''; Italian: ''Don Camillo'') film was remade in 1983, an Italian production with [[Terence Hill]] directing and also starring as Don Camillo. [[Colin Blakely]] performed Peppone in one of his last film roles.<ref>{{IMDb title|0085454|Don Camillo (1984)}}</ref>
===Radio=== A [[BBC Radio]] English-language radio dramatization of ''The Little World of Don Camillo'' was broadcast in 2001 starring [[Alun Armstrong (actor)|Alun Armstrong]] as Don Camillo, [[John Moffatt (actor)|John Moffatt]] as the Bishop, [[Shaun Prendergast]] as Peppone and [[Joss Ackland]] as God, and rebroadcast in July 2010 on [[BBC Radio 7]].
Four further [[BBC Radio]] series of ''The Little World of Don Camillo'' were made, with the final series broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] in December 2006.<ref name =BBC>{{Citation | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/littleworldofdoncamillo/pip/1yqsz/ | publisher = The BBC | title = Radio 4 | contribution = The little world of don Camillo | place = [[United Kingdom|UK]]}}</ref> [[Ian Hogg (actor)|Ian Hogg]] replaced Armstrong as Don Camillo, while Prendergast, Ackland and Moffatt all continued to reprise their roles as Peppone, God and the Bishop respectively. [[BBC Radio 7]] broadcast the second and third series throughout August and September 2010 with the fourth series beginning on 6 October.<ref name =BBC2>{{Citation | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00v2rv2/ | publisher = The BBC | title = Radio 7 | contribution = Programmes | place = UK}}</ref>
===Television=== In 1980, the [[BBC]] produced the television series ''The Little World of Don Camillo'', based on the stories, starring Italian-German actor [[Mario Adorf]] as Don Camillo and Englishman [[Brian Blessed]] as Peppone. The narrator and Voice of the Christ was [[Cyril Cusack]].
In Colombia the stories were adapted into a TV comedy called ''Don Camilo''. The Italian Communist era was changed to a Colombian period called "La Violencia" when the Liberal and Conservative parties were fighting to maintain power in Colombia. The comedy was produced from 1987 to 1988 by the now defunct Coestrellas company and produced and directed by Daniel Samper Pizano and Bernando Romero Pereiro. The series starred [[Carlos Benjumea]] as Don Camillo (Don Camilo in Colombian Spanish), [[Hector Rivas]] as Peppone (Pepón in Colombian Spanish), Luis Fernando Múnera as The Christ Voice, and the actors Diego León Hoyos and Manuel Pachón as Peppone flunkies. The series was broadcast on Mondays at 10:00 pm by [[Canal A|Cadena 2]] ([[Señal Institucional]] now) and rebroadcast by [[Señal Colombia]] in 2011 and [[Canal Uno]] in 2014.
===Thai Novel=== ''The Little World of Don Camillo'' was adapted by the [[Thai people|Thai]] writer and politician [[Kukrit Pramoj]] into his own 1954 novel, ''Phai Daeng'' (Red Bamboo).
==See also== {{portal |Novels}} *[[Marcelino pan y vino]] also features a talking crucifix *[[Monsignor Quixote]] ([[Graham Greene]] novel about friendship between priest and Communist mayor)
==References== {{Reflist }}
==Sources== * {{cite book|first = Riccardo F.| last = Esposito | title = Don Camillo e Peppone. Cronache cinematografiche dalla Bassa Padana 1951–1965 | publisher = Le Mani – Microart's | location = [[Recco]] | year = 2008 | ISBN = 978-88-8012-455-9 | language = Italian}}.
== External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.doncamillo.net/ The Little Blog of Don Camillo] * {{Citation | url = http://www.doncamillo.homepage.t-online.de/ | title = Auf den Spuren von Don Camillo und Peppone | publisher = T online | place = [[Germany|DE]] | language = German}}. * {{Citation | url = http://ordenssekretariat-shop.fineartprint.de/ | contribution = Don Camillo | type = cartoons | title = Ordenßekretariat | publisher = Fine art print | place = [[Germany|DE]] | language = German}}. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160322033132/http://www.imdb.com/character/ch0027340/ Don Camillo] on [[IMDb]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Camillo, Don}} [[Category:20th-century Italian novels|Don Camillo]] [[Category:Fictional Italian people in literature]] [[Category:Fictional priests and priestesses]] [[Category:Series of books|Don Camillo]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1948]]

revision.comment: Srnec moved page [[Eric Chronicles]] to [[Eric Chronicle]]
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} The '''''Eric Chronicle''''' (Swedish: ''Erikskrönikan'') is the oldest surviving Swedish [[chronicle]]. It was written by an unknown author (or, less probably, several authors) between about 1320 and 1335.
It is the oldest in a group of medieval rhymed chronicles recounting political events in Sweden. It is one of Sweden's earliest and most important narrative sources. Its authorship and precise political significance and biases are debated, but it is clear that the chronicle's protagonist and hero is [[Eric, Duke of Södermanland]], brother of King [[Birger, King of Sweden|Birger of Sweden]].
The chronicle is written in ''[[knittelvers]]'', a form of [[doggerel]], and in its oldest version is 4543 lines long. It begins in 1229, with the reign of [[Eric XI of Sweden]] (d. 1250) but focuses on the period 1250-1319, ending in the year when the three-year-old [[Magnus IV of Sweden]] came to the throne. It survives in six manuscripts from the fifteenth century and a further fourteen from the sixteenth and seventeenth.
==Example==
{| class="wikitable" | {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} :Dödhin han er ekke söther :thz rönte herra jwan :en höwelik riddare ok wäl dan :han war ther skutin i häll :thz edde hertoganom ekke wäl :En riddare heyt gudzsär :han fik ther ok slikt sama wärk :han hörde konung birge till :mannen dör tho han ey will :Ther miste han sith liiff :fult gaff han fore thera kiiff
{{col-break|gap=5em}} :Death is not mild: :Sir Ivan experienced it, :a courteous, excellent knight: :an arrow transfixed him and he died. :The duke was not happy for that. :A knight's name was Gudsärk, :the same thing happened to him, :he was one of King Birger's men. :Men die even if they don't want: :he lost his life, :he paid for their conflict.<ref>Lines 3269-79, quoted and translated by Fulvio Ferrari, 'Literature as a Performative Act: ''Erikskrönikan'' and the Making of a Nation', in ''Lärdomber oc skämptan: Medieval Swedish Literature Reconsidered'', ed. by Massimiliano Bampi and Fulvio Ferrari, Samlingar utgivna av Svenska fornskriftsällskapet, serie 3: Smärre texter och undersökningar, 5 (Uppsala: Svenska fornskriftsällskapet, 2008), pp. 55-80 (p. 68), here with minor amendments to punctuation.</ref> {{col-end}} |}
==External links== * [http://runeberg.org/erikkron Eric's Chronicle]. Original text (old Swedish). * [https://books.google.com/books?id=2gIK29dXvMAC&lpg=PA260&ots=QoGwJ98DQY&dq=Kristina%20Tyrgilsdotter&pg=PA102#v=onepage&q=Kristina%20Tyrgilsdotter&f=false translation into modern english]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Swedish chronicles]] [[Category:Swedish literature]] [[Category:13th century in Sweden]] [[Category:14th century in Sweden]] [[Category:Works of unknown authorship]]
{{sweden-hist-stub}}

page.title: Flora of Fuegia, the Falkland Islands, etc

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = ''Flora of Fuegia, the Falkland Islands, etc'' | image = | caption = | author = [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] | illustrator = [[Walter Hood Fitch]] | country = England | language = English | series = Monthly parts | subject = [[Botany]] | genre = | publisher = Reeve Brothers | pub_date = 1845 – 1847 | pages = | wikisource = }}
The '''''Flora of Fuegia, the Falkland Islands, etc.''''' is a description of the plants discovered in these islands during the [[Ross expedition]] written by [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] and published by Reeve Brothers in London between 1845 and 1847.<ref>{{cite book|author= Joseph Dalton Hooker|year= 1844|title= Flora Antarctica, Volume 1, Parts 1-2, Flora Novae-Zelandiae - The Botany of the Antarctic Voyage of H.M. Discovery Ships Erebus and Terror in the years 1839-1843|pages= title pages|publisher= Reeve Brothers|location= London|url= https://archive.org/stream/botanyofantarcti01hook#page/31/mode/1up}}</ref> Hooker sailed on [[HMS Erebus (1826)|HMS ''Erebus'']] as assistant surgeon.<ref>{{cite web|website= Kew Royal Botanic Gardens|title= The Erebus voyage|url= http://www.kew.org/learn/library-art-archives/joseph-hooker/about-joseph-hooker/erebus-voyage|accessdate=2015-11-28}}</ref> It was the second in a series of four Floras in the ''[[Flora Antarctica]]'', the others being the ''[[Flora of Lord Auckland and Campbell's Islands]]'' (1843-1845), the ''[[Flora Novae-Zelandiae]]'' (1851–53), and the ''[[Flora Tasmaniae]]'' (1853–59). They were "splendidly" illustrated by [[Walter Hood Fitch]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Curtis |first1=Winifred M. |title=Hooker, Sir Joseph Dalton (1817-1911) |work=Australian Dictionary of Biography (Volume 4) |date=1972 |publisher=MUP |url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hooker-sir-joseph-dalton-3789}}</ref>
The larger part of the plant specimens collected during the Ross expedition are now part of the [[Kew Gardens#Herbarium|Kew Herbarium]].<ref>{{cite journal|author1=David Goyder |author2=Pat Griggs |author3=Mark Nesbitt |author4=Lynn Parker |author5=Kiri Ross-Jones |year=2012 |title=Sir Joseph Hooker's Collections at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|journal= Curtis's Botanical Magazine |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=66–85 |url= http://www.kew.org/sites/default/files/assets/KPPCONT_085462.pdf}}</ref>
== Context == {{main article|Ross expedition|Flora Antarctica}}
The British government fitted out [[Ross expedition|an expedition]] led by [[James Clark Ross]] to investigate magnetism and marine geography in high southern latitudes, which sailed with two ships, [[HMS Terror (1813)|HMS ''Terror'']] and [[HMS Erebus (1826)|HMS ''Erebus'']] on 29 September 1839 from Chatham.
The ships arrived, after several stops, at the [[Cape of Good Hope]] on 4 April 1840. On 21 April the giant kelp ''[[Macrocystis pyrifera]]'' was found off [[Prince Edward Islands|Marion Island]], but no landfall could be made there or on the [[Crozet Islands]] due to the harsh winds. On 12 May the ships anchored at Christmas Harbour for two and a half months, during which all the plant species previously encountered by [[James Cook]] on the [[Kerguelen Islands]] were collected. On 16 August they reached the [[River Derwent (Tasmania)|River Derwent]], remaining in Tasmania until 12 November. A week later the flotilla stopped at [[Auckland Islands|Lord Auckland's Islands]] and [[Campbell Island group|Campbell's Island]] for the spring months.
Large floating forests of ''Macrocystis'' and ''[[Durvillaea]]'' were found until the ships ran into icebergs at latitude 61° S. [[Drift ice|Pack-ice]] was met at 68° S and longitude 175°. During this part of the voyage [[Victoria Land]], [[Mount Erebus]] and [[Mount Terror (Antarctica)|Mount Terror]] were discovered. After returning to Tasmania for three months, the flotilla went via Sydney to the [[Bay of Islands]], and stayed for three months in New Zealand to collect plants there. After visiting other islands, the ships returned to the Cape of Good Hope on 4 April 1843. At the end of the journey specimens of some fifteen hundred plant species had been collected and preserved.<ref>{{cite book |author=J.D. Hooker |year=1844 |title= Flora Antarctica, Volume 1, Parts 1-2, Flora Novae-Zelandiae|pages= v-vii |url=https://archive.org/stream/botanyofantarcti01hook#page/31/mode/1up}}</ref>
==Species==
Hooker collected the following plants from the lands named in the book's title.
=== Seedplants ===
{{div col}} * ''[[Adesmia lotoides]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> ([[Strait of Magellan]], Cape Gregory, Elisabeth island) * ''[[Adesmia pumila]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Gregory, Cabo Negro) * ''[[Anemone decapetala]]'' <small>Ard.</small> (Patagonia) * ''Arenaria media'' ([[Tres Montes Peninsula|Cabo Tres Montes]], St. Salvador Bay on the Falklands) = ''[[Spergularia media]]'' <small>(L.) C.Presl</small> * ''[[Arabis macloviana]]'' <small>Hook.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Azara lanceolata]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (South Chile, Cabo Tres Montes) * ''Berberis buxifolia'' <small>Lam.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego) = ''[[Berberis microphylla]]'' <small>G. Forst.</small> * ''[[Berberis empetrifolia]]'' <small>Lam.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine) * ''[[Berberis ilicifolia]]'' <small>Forst.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego) * ''[[Caltha appendiculata]]'' <small>Pers.</small> (Tierra del Fuego) * ''[[Caltha dionaeifolia]]'' <small>Hook.</small> (Hermite Islands) * ''[[Caltha sagittata]]'' <small>Cavanilles</small> (Tierra del Fuego, Port Famine, Hermite Islands, Falklands) * ''[[Cardamine geranifolia]]'' <small>DC.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego, Port Famine, Hermite Islands) * ''[[Cardamine hirsuta]]'' <small>L.</small> (Tierra del Fuego, Falklands, Tristan da Cunha) * ''[[Cerastium arvense]]'' <small>L.</small> (Tierra del Fuego, Falklands) * ''C. vulgatum'' (Falklands) = ''[[Cerastium fontanum|C. fontanum]]'' <small>Baumg.</small> * ''Colletia discolor'' <small>Hook.</small> = ''[[Discaria chacaye]]'' <small>(G.Don) Tortosa</small> * ''Colobanthus crassifolius'' (Strait of Magellan, [[Cape Horn]], Cape Famine, Hermite Islands, Falklands) = ''[[Colobanthus quitensis]]'' <small>(Kunth) Bartl.</small> *''[[Colobanthus diffusus]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> ([[Île Amsterdam|Amsterdam Island]]) * ''[[Colobanthus kerguelensis]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Kerguellen Islands) * ''[[Colobanthus subulatus]]'' <small>(d’Urv.) Hook.f.</small> (Good Success Bay, Hermite Islands, Cape Horn, Tierra del Fuego, Falklands) * ''Draba falklandica'' (Falklands) = ''[[Draba magellanica]]'' <small>Lam.</small> * ''[[Draba funiculosa]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> * ''Draba incana'' var. ''magellanica'' (Strait of Magellan) = ''Draba magellanica'' * ''[[Drimys winteri]]'' <small>Forst.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego) * ''[[Drosera uniflora]]'' <small>Willd.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine) * ''Geranium intermedium'' <small>Bert., 1832, non James, 1823</small> ([[Chonos Archipelago]]) = ''[[Geranium berteroanum]]'' <small>Colla, 1834</small> * ''[[Geranium magellanicum]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Strait of Magellan, [[Isabel Island (Chile)|Elizabeth Island]]) * ''Geranium patagonicum'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine) = ''G. berteroanum'' * ''[[Geranium sessiliflorum]]'' <small>Cav.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Cabo Negro) * ''[[Hamadryas argentea]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Hamadryas kingii]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''[[Hamadryas magelhanica]]'' <small>Lam.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''Lychnis magellanica'' (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine, Cabo Negro) = ''[[Silene magellanica]]'' <small>(Desr.) Bocquet</small> * ''Myginda distycha'' = ''[[Maytenus disticha]]'' <small>(Hook.f.) Urb.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine) * ''[[Maytenus magellanica]]'' (Magellan's mayten) <small>(Lam.) Hook.f.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Famine) * ''[[Oxalis enneaphylla]]'' <small>Cav.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Oxalis magellanica]]'' <small>Forst.</small> (Cabo Tres Montes, Hermite Islands) * ''[[Pringlea antiscorbutica]]'' <small>R.Br.</small> (Kerguellen Islands) (Kerguelen cabbage) * ''[[Ranunculus biternatus]]'' <small>Duch.</small> (Patagonia, Falklands, Hermite Islands) * ''[[Ranunculus chilensis]]'' <small>DC.</small> (Cabo Tres Montes, Chonos Archipelago) * ''[[Ranunculus crassipes]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Kerguellen Islands) * ''[[Ranunculus maclovianus]]'' <small>d'Urv.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Ranunculus peduncularis]]'' <small>Sm.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''[[Ranunculus sericocephalus]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Ranunculus hydrophilus]]'' <small>Gaud.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Ranunculus trullifolius]]'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Falklands) * ''[[Sagina procumbens]]'' <small>L.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''Senebierra australis'' <small>Hook.f.</small> (Chonos Archipellago) = ''[[Lepidium pseudodidymus]]'' <small>Thell. ex Druce</small> * ''Sisymbrium magellanicum'' (Strait of Magellan) = ''[[Polypsecadium magellanicum]]'' <small>(Juss. ex Pers.) Al-Shehbaz</small> * ''Sisymbrium sophia'' (Strait of Magellan, Cape Negro<!--- couldn't find it in Patagonia --->) = ''[[Descurainia sophia]]'' <small>(L.) Webb ex Prantl</small> * ''[[Stellaria debilis]]'' <small>d'Urv</small> ([[Isla de los Estados]], Falklands) * ''[[Stellaria lanceolata]]'' <small>Poir.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''Stellaria media'' (Falklands, Amsterdam Island) (probably introduced) * ''Stellaria rotundifolia'' (Strait of Magellan) = ''[[Drymaria rotundifolia]]'' <small>A.Gray</small> * ''[[Thlaspi magellanicum]]'' <small>Pers. non Comm. ex Poir.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''[[Viola maculata]]'' <small>Cav.</small> (Strait of Magellan) * ''[[Viola magellanica]]'' <small>Forst.</small> (South part of Tierra del Fuego, Isla de los Estados, Falklands) * ''[[Viola commersonii]]'' <small>DC. ex Ging.</small> (Strait of Magellan, Port Gallant, South part of Tierra del Fuego) * ''[[Viola tridentata]]'' <small>Menz.</small> (Isla de los Estados, Port Famine, Hermite Islands, Falklands).<ref>{{cite book|author= J.D. Hooker|year= 1844|title= Flora Antarctica, Volume 1, Parts 1-2, Flora Novae-Zelandiae|pages= 223–251|url= https://archive.org/stream/botanyofantarcti01hook#page/223/mode/1up}}</ref> {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist|28em}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Hatheway House | nrhp_type = | image = Phelps-HathawayHousesideview1.JPG | caption = | location= 55 S. Main St., [[Suffield, Connecticut]] | coordinates={{coord|41|58|48|N|72|39|10|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Connecticut#USA | built = {{Start date|1762}} | architect = Benjamin, Asher | architecture = Georgian | added = August 6, 1975 | area = less than one acre | refnum = 75001934<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | nrhp_type2 = cp | designated_nrhp_type2 = September 25, 1979 | partof = [[Suffield Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 79003750 }} The '''Hatheway House''', also known as the '''Phelps-Hatheway House & Garden''' is a [[historic house museum]] at 55 South Main Street in [[Suffield, Connecticut]]. The sprawling house has sections built as early as 1732, with significant alterations made in 1795 to a design by [[Asher Benjamin]] for [[Oliver Phelps]], a major land speculator. The house provides a window into a wide variety of 18th-century home construction methods. It is now maintained by [[Connecticut Landmarks]], and is open seasonally between May and October. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1975.<ref name="nris"/>
==Description and history== The Hatheway House is located in the village center of Suffield, on the west side of South Main Street, south of its junction with Bridge Street. It is a sprawling multi-section wood frame structure, with a 2-1/2 story five-bay central block flanked on the north by a 2-1/2 story three-bay section and on the left by a 1-1/2 story ell. Each section is covered by gambrel roof and is sheated in wooden clapboards. The center block, built in 1762, has a large central chimney, and its interior is finished with high-quality Georgian woodwork. The southern ell is an older structure with simple finishes, and may date as far back as 1732. The northern addition was added in 1795. The main entrance is at the center of the main block, sheltered by a Doric portico designed by Asher Benjamin and added in 1795. Outbuildings on the property include a carriage house and barn, both 19th-century structures.<ref name=NRHP>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|75001934}}|title=NRHP nomination for Hatheway House|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-07-08}}</ref>
The main block of the house was built about 1762, probably by Abraham Burbank, and was originally more plainly decorated with a gable roof. Burbank's son Shem sold the house to Oliver Phelps in 1788. Phelps, then already a man of some wealth and sophistication, transformed the house into the mansion it is now. Phelps was a principal in the [[Phelps and Gorham Purchase]] of six million acres of land in upstate [[New York (state)|New York]], making him one of the nation's largest landowners. Phelps lived here until 1802, when he moved to [[Canandaigua, New York]], to more closely oversee the development and sale of his holdings.<ref name=NRHP/>
==See also== *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hartford County, Connecticut]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ctlandmarks.org/phelps-hatheway Phelps-Hatheway House web site]
{{National Register of Historic Places}}
