Knopf | year = 1946 | isbn = 0-520-05665-5 | location = New York | oclc = 7001196 | author2 = Putnam, Samuel }} * {{Cite journal | last = Joyner | first = Kara | date = August 2005 | title = Interracial Relationships and the Transition to Adulthood | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/asoca/asr/2005/00000070/00000004/art00002 | journal = American Sociological Review | publisher = American Sociological Association | volume = 70 | issue = 4 | pages = 563–81 | doi = 10.1177/000312240507000402 | author2 = Kao, Grace | accessdate = 14 July 2008 }} * {{Cite book | title = The Rebirth of Hope: My Journey from Vietnam War Child to American Citizen] | last = Hudecek | first = Sau Le | publisher = Texas Christian University Press | year = 2017 | isbn = 0875654320 | location = Texas | url = https://www.amazon.com/Rebirth-Hope-Journey-Vietnam-American/dp/0875654320/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1496787362&sr=8-1&keywords=the+rebirth+of+hope }}

;Advocacy groups * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060813110446/http://www.ameasite.org/ Association of MultiEthnic Americans, Inc.], US * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100204100412/http://blendedpeopleamerica.com/ Blended People of America], US-based nonprofit organization representing the interests of the mixed-race community * [http://www.nacaomestica.org Brazilian Multiracial Movement], Brazilian mixed-race organization * [http://www.hafujapanese.org The Hafu Project], a study of half-Japanese people, London-, Munich-, Tokyo-based nonprofit organisation * [http://www.mavinfoundation.org MAVIN Foundation], an organization advocating for mixed heritage people and families * [http://www.mixedraceuk.com Mixed Race UK], UK-based nonprofit organization representing the interests of the mixed-race community * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081006084015/http://www.mosaicequalities.org.uk/ Mosiac UK], a UK-based organisation for mixed race families * [http://www.pih.org.uk People in Harmony UK] * [http://www.swirlinc.org Swirl], US-based mixed community

revision.text:
[[File:The grave of Philip Conisbee, Highgate Cemetery, London.jpg|thumb|The grave of Philip Conisbee, Highgate Cemetery, London]] '''Philip Conisbee''' (January 3, 1946 – January 16, 2008) was a British-American curator for the American [[National Gallery of Art]].<ref>Johnson, Ken (January 25, 2008). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/25/arts/design/25conisbee.html?_r=0 Philip Conisbee, 62, National Gallery Curator, Is Dead]." ''The New York Times''. Retrieved June 20, 2015.</ref>
==Life==
Philip was born in [[Belfast]], the son of Paul Conisbee, but raised in [[London]], being educated at St Dunstan's College in [[Catford]] before earning a BA in European Art at the [[Courtauld Institute]] in 1968.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/mar/13/art.usa|title=Obituary: Philip Conisbee|first=Elizabeth|last=Cropper|date=13 March 2008|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
Continuing in academia he received a doctorate for his thesis on the French landscape artist [[Claude Joseph Vernet]] in 1971. From 1971 to 1986 he lectured at [[Leicester University]]. He then moved to America to act as Curator of French Art at the Museum of Fine Art in Boston.
He befriended [[Earl Powell III]] and moved to [[California]] to work with him at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] in 1988. Powell moved to Washington in 1992 and asked Conisbee to join him the following year.
He became a US citizen in 1994.
He rose to be Curator of the National Gallery of Art in Washington D.C.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/25/arts/design/25conisbee.html|title=Philip Conisbee - Obituary|first=Ken|last=Johnson|date=4 May 2018|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In 1998 he organised one of the country's most successful exhibitions: ''Van Gogh's Van Gogh''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/18/AR2008011803309.html|title=Philip Conisbee; National Gallery Curator|first=Matt|last=Schudel|date=19 January 2008|publisher=|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref>
In 2003 the French government awarded him ''Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thearttribune.com/Death-of-Philip-Conisbee.html|title=Death of Philip Conisbee - The Art Tribune|website=www.thearttribune.com}}</ref>
He died of [[lung cancer]] in [[Georgetown, Washington D.C.]], but is buried in [[Highgate Cemetery]] in north [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arthistorians.info/conisbeep|title=Conisbee, Philip|first=|last=admin|date=21 February 2018|website=arthistorians.info}}</ref>
==Family==
Conisbee first married Susan Baer, with whom he had two children. Following divorce he married Faya Causey, who survived him.<ref name="auto"/>
==Selected publications== see<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s?ie=UTF8&page=1&rh=n:283155,p_27:Philip+Conisbee|title=Amazon.com: Philip Conisbee: Books|website=www.amazon.com}}</ref> *''Chardin'' (1985) *''Painting in 18th-Century France'' (1981) *''In the Light of Italy: Corot and Early Open-Air Painting'' (1996) *''George de la Tour and his World'' (1996) *''Portraits by Ingres: Image of an Epoch'' (1999) *''Cezanne in Provence'' (2006)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Conisbee, Philip}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:American curators]] [[Category:National Gallery of Art]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Burials at Highgate Cemetery]] [[Category:People from Belfast]] [[Category:People educated at St Dunstan's College]] [[Category:Alumni of the Courtauld Institute of Art]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Leicester]] [[Category:Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] [[Category:Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] [[Category:English emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Deaths from lung cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Washington, D.C.]]

{{About|a specifying a method for performing a task in telecommunications|other uses|Procedure (disambiguation){{!}}Procedure}} {{Underlinked|date=February 2013}}
A '''procedure''' is a document written to support a "policy directive". A procedure is designed to describe [[5 Ws|who, what, where, when, and why]] by means of establishing [[corporate accountability]] in support of the implementation of a "policy".
The "how" is further documented by each organizational unit in the form of "work instructions" which aims to further support a procedure by providing greater detail.
==Exemplary procedure== {{unreferenced section|date=November 2016}} As an example, suppose a manufacturing facility established a policy that all overtime shall be approved. A procedure can be created to establish “Who” can approve overtime (ranks, roles & responsibilities), "What" forms or systems must be used, "Where" they are located, "When" overtime is applicable, and "Why" (i.e., the management directive established via a "policy"). The output of a procedure is an input to a "work instruction" (i.e., a set of [[Action (philosophy)|actions]] or operations which must be executed in the same manner in order to achieve intended results under the same circumstances. (For example, in the latter example, the output of the procedure could be further broken down into a work instruction to describe "how" a manager/employee should access the systems for approving/reviewing overtime (e.g., first click on this hyperlink, second press this button, third choose these fields, and fourth click approve/reject).
USAGE EXAMPLES
•The insurance company provides a step-by-step guide to its dispute and complaint procedures for all policy holders to access.
•The Doctor surprised me when he told me that he had used a new procedure to repair the tear in the tendon of my leg.
•In a work place that has complex interactions among employees, it is important to specify and implement a procedure for core processes.
==Specific types of procedures== In telecommunications, a '''SOP''' ([[Standard Operating Procedure]]) is specifically designed to describe and guide multiple iterations of the same procedure over a broad number of locations, on multiple occasions, and over an open period of time until such '''SOP''' is updated or discontinued. Also used heavily in the telecommunications industry, a '''MOP''' (Method of Procedure) differs from a '''SOP''' in that it contains specific directives for a particular activity, on a particular date, for a specific location, piece of equipment, or circumstance. In today's business model, wherein telecom providers can be both "provider" and "user", most "user" organizations require a '''MOP''' from the service provider whenever an activity has the potential to cause a traffic-affecting outage.
The industry standard is <50ms of traffic interruption. If a "switch hit" or traffic interruption is 50 ms or less, it is "transparent" to the bit stream carrying the traffic, and is therefore considered "hitless" and non-traffic affecting.<ref name=undefined>{{cite book|title=The Froehlich/Kent Encyclopedia of Telecommunications, Volume 3; Volume 16 |authors=Froehlich, Fritz E. & [[Allen Kent|Kent, Allen]] & Hall, Carolyn M. |page=342}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Standard operating procedure]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Technical communication]] [[Category:Operating procedures]]

{{Infobox political party | country = Spain |name = Republican Social Movement | native_name = Movimiento Social Republicano |logo = Logomsr.jpg |logo_size = 120px | colorcode = {{Republican Social Movement/meta/color}} | secretary = Antonio Martínez Cayuela | foundation = 1999 | dissolution = 2018 | predecessor = | ideology = [[Falangism]]
[[Palingenetic ultranationalism|Revolutionary nationalism]]
[[Republicanism in Spain|Republicanism]]http://www.msr.org.es/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=414:estatutos-del-movimiento-social-republicano&catid=38:documentos&Itemid=56{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
[[Spanish unionism]] | position = [[Far-right]] | european = | europarl = | international = [[Alliance of European National Movements]] | colours = Black and Red |seats1_title = [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|350|hex={{Republican Social Movement/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[Senate of Spain|Senate]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|266|hex={{Republican Social Movement/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|54|hex={{Republican Social Movement/meta/color}}}} |seats4_title = |seats4 = | headquarters = | website = [http://www.msr.org.es/ www.msr.org.es] }} [[File:Manifamsr.jpg|right|thumb|MSR demonstration in 2013.]] The '''Republican Social Movement''' ({{lang-es|Movimiento Social Republicano}}, '''MSR''') was a [[Third Position|third positionist]] [[political party]] in [[Spain]]. It was registered at the Ministry of Interior on November 30, 1999, with offices in [[Barcelona]]. The following year it merged with Vértice Social Español to form what it called a "Social Patriotic force". By its members' own admission, as well as by that of the bulk of the far-right public opinion,[https://web.archive.org/web/20050321090806/http://www.libreopinion.com/members/ch1492/english/FascioInSpain.html] the MSR was roughly inscribed in what is usually called the [[Third Position]], and adheres to the commonplace strategy of defending socializing (and at times [[leftist]]) doctrines abroad, whereas adopting conservative and anti-immigration stances at a domestic level. {{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} Its slogan was 'Spain-Republic-[[Socialization (economics)|Socialization]]'. In the VII National Congress all the partecipants decided to terminate the movement's experience. So MSR dissolved itself with an official announcement 30 of January 2018.title = ''Official communique of Republican Social Movement''|https://movimientosocialrepublicano.wordpress.com/ ==Policies== The party has campaigned against [[Immigration to Spain|immigration into Spain]], [[Turkish membership]] of the [[European Union]] and global capitalism. They support a large programme of re-nationalisation of industries such as electricity and transport. In terms of foreign policies the party takes a strongly pro-[[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] approach to the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict|Middle East question]], criticising [[Israel]] alleging that the "Zionist army are committing daily crimes against the Palestinian people." In addition to supporting the Venezuelan government of [[Hugo Chavez]], they have also called for the withdrawal of Spanish troops in the Balkans and condemned the American led [[invasion of Iraq]]. In the [[Spanish general election, 2000|2000 General Election]] the party supported the platform of [[España 2000]]. ==Press== The party publishes ''Tribuna de Europa'' and ''Libertad''. ==Sectoral organizations== *Labour: ''Unión Sindical de Trabajadores - UST'' *Youth: ''Liga Joven'' *Ecology: ''Hispania Verde'' *Think-tank: ''Alternativa Europea'' *Culture: ''Círculo de Estudios La Emboscadura - CELE'' ==Elections results== ===Congress of Deputies / Senate=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:100%; line-height:16px;" |- ! rowspan="2" width="50px"| Election ! colspan="5"| [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]] ! colspan="2"| [[Senate (Spain)|Senate]] ! rowspan="2" width="30px"| Rank ! rowspan="2" width="125px"| Government ! rowspan="2"| Leader |- ! width="75px"| Votes ! width="45px"| % ! width="45px"| ±[[Percentage point|pp]] ! width="100px"| Seats won ! width="40px"| +/− ! width="100px"| Seats won ! width="40px"| +/− |- ! [[Spanish general election, 2004|2004]] | 6,768 | 0.03% | {{increase}} | {{Composition bar|0|470|hex={{Communist Party of Spain/meta/color}}}} | ±0 | {{N/A}} | {{N/A}} | #36 | style="background-color:#DDDDDD"| No seats | |} ===European Parliament=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Election year ! # of total votes ! % of overall vote ! # of seats won ! Rank |- ! [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Spain)|2014]] | style="text-align:center;"| 8,909 {{increase}} | style="text-align:center;"| 0.06% {{increase}} | style="text-align:center;"|{{Composition bar|0|12|hex={{UK Independence Party/meta/color}}}} | style="text-align:center;"| 31 {{increase}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |last=Büttner |first= Frauke|date=2011 |title=Right-wing extremism in Spain: Between parliamentary right-wing extremism in Spain: Between parliamentary insignificance, far-right populism and racist violence |url= http://library.fes.de/pdf-files/do/08338.pdf|location= |publisher= |pages= 181|isbn=978-3-86872-617-6 |accessdate=2014-04-03 }} ==External links== *[http://www.msr.org.es/ MSR website] *[https://twitter.com/MSR_int MSR Twitter in English] {{Alliance of European National Movements}} [[Category:Far-right political parties in Spain]] [[Category:Fascist parties in Spain]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Spain]] [[Category:Neo-fascist parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1999]] [[Category:Republican parties in Spain]] [[Category:Spanish nationalism]] [[Category:Right-wing populism in Europe]] [[Category:Third Position]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2018]]

A '''search domain''' is a domain used as part of a domain search list. The domain search list, as well as the local domain name, is used by a [[Domain Name System#DNS_resolvers|resolver]] to create a [[Fully qualified domain name|fully qualified domain name (FQDN)]] from a relative name.{{cite web |last1=Mockapetris|first1=P.V. |title=Domain names - concepts and facilities |url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1034 |website=IETF Documents |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] |accessdate=24 July 2017 |language=en|format=HTML |doi=10.17487/RFC1034 |date=November 1987 |quote=Relative names are either taken relative to a well known origin, or to a list of domains used as a search list. Relative names appear mostly at the user interface, where their interpretation varies from implementation to implementation, and in master files, where they are relative to a single origin domain name. The most common interpretation uses the root "." as either the single origin or as one of the members of the search list, so a multi-label relative name is often one where the trailing dot has been omitted to save typing.}} For this purpose, the local domain name functions as a single-item search list. ==IPv4== In an IPv4 environment, search domains are often set via DHCPv4, along with the local domain name. The domain search list is configured by the ''Domain Search Option'' (DHCPv4 option number 119), while the local domain name is configured by ''Domain Name'' (DHCPv4 option number 15).{{cite web |doi=10.17487/RFC3397 |last1=Bernard|first1=Aboba |last2=Stuart|first2=Cheshire |title=RFC 3397 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Domain Search Option |url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3397 |website=IETF Documents |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] |date=November 2002 |accessdate=22 July 2017 |language=en |format=HTML}}{{cite web |last1=Alexander|first1=Steve |last2=Droms|first2=Ralph |title=DHCP Options and BOOTP Vendor Extensions |url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2132#section-3.17 |website=IETF Documents |publisher=IETF |accessdate=24 July 2017 |location=section 3.17 |page=10 |language=en |format=HTML |doi=10.17487/RFC2132 |date=March 1997 |quote=3.17. Domain Name
This option specifies the domain name that client should use when resolving hostnames via the Domain Name System.
The code for this option is 15.}} The Windows operating system, however, does not understand the Domain Search Option; as a workaround, many network administrators use Group Policy Objects to set the domain search list for Windows machines.{{cite web |last1=Zuba|first1=Matt |title=Windows Server 2008 RC2 DHCP Server Option 119 - Matt Zuba |url=https://www.mattzuba.com/2011/03/windows-2008-rc2-dhcp-server-option-119/ |website=Matt Zuba |accessdate=22 July 2017 |date=16 March 2011}} ==IPv6== In an IPv6 environment, the domain search list is called a DNS Search List (DNSSL) and can be configured by Router Advertisement and DHCP.{{cite web|last1=Droms|first1=Ralph|title=RFC 3646 - DNS Configuration options for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6 (DHCPv6)|url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3646|website=IETF Documents|publisher=IETF|accessdate=24 July 2017|language=en|format=HTML|doi=10.17487/RFC3646}} ==Manually configuring domain search lists== In Linux it can be defined by editing the ifcfg file corresponding to the network.{{Cite web |url=http://superuser.com/questions/110808/how-can-i-add-additional-search-domains-to-the-resolv-conf-created-by-dhclient-i/466912 |title=How can I add additional search domains to the resolv.conf created by dhclient in CentOS |website=Super User |access-date=2016-12-18}} In [[Mac OS X]] the setting is located under the [[Domain Name System|DNS]] tab, next to DNS server settings. A similar setting in [[Microsoft Windows]] is the '''Connection-specific DNS Suffix'''. ==Functionality== When looking up a bare name in DNS, the network stack will add the search domains to it to form fully qualified domain names, and look up those as well.{{cite web |title=OS X Mountain Lion: Edit DNS and search domain settings |url=https://support.apple.com/kb/PH11162 |website=Apple Support |accessdate=22 July 2017 |date=4 September 2015}} For example, if the domain search list contains "wikipedia.org", typing "en" in the browser will direct the user to "en.wikipedia.org". Some [[Internet Service Provider|ISPs]] add their own search domains via DHCP settings, similar to how they add DNS servers and other networking information; if this is undesired, the user can change this setting to ".local". ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Domain Name System]] * [[Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol#DHCP_options|DHCP Options]] [[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:Network service]] {{network-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox Organization|name=Society of Genealogists|image=[[File:Society_of_Genealogists_Logo.jpg]]|image_border=|size=|caption=Society of Genealogists logo|map=|msize=|mcaption=|abbreviation=SoG|motto=|formation=1911|type=|status=|purpose=|headquarters=[[London]]|location=|membership=11,000|language=|main_organ=|parent_organization=|affiliations=|num_staff=|num_volunteers=|budget=|website=[http://www.sog.org.uk/ www.sog.org.uk]|remarks=}}[[Image:SOG Harrington Gardens.jpg|260px|right|thumb|Before moving to north London, the SoG owned & operated from this building at 37 [[Harrington Gardens]], near [[Gloucester Road tube station]] SW7.]] The '''Society of Genealogists''' (SoG) is a UK-based educational charity, founded in 1911<ref name="Making History">Fowler, S. [http://www.history.ac.uk/makinghistory/resources/articles/society_genealogists.html Making History: Society of Genealogists], School of Advanced Study, University of London. Date unknown. Retrieved 2011-10-30.</ref> to "promote, encourage and foster the study, science and knowledge of [[genealogy]]".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Foster|first1=J|last2=Sheppard|first2=J|title=British Archives: A Guide to Archive Resources in the UK|date=2002|publisher=Palgrave|location=New York, NY|isbn=9780333735367|page=xxvii|edition=4th}}</ref> The Society's Library is the largest specialist genealogical library outside North America.<ref name="Making History" /> Membership is open to any adult who agrees to abide by the Society's rules and who pays the annual subscription. At the end of 2010, it had 11,014 members.<ref>Society of Genealogists, ''Annual Report & Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2010''.</ref>
==History== Until it purchased 37 Harrington Gardens, [[South Kensington]], in 1954, the Society was based in Malet Place, [[Bloomsbury]], London. The constant growth of the library and increasingly cramped building forced the Society to also sell this headquarters and move both to 14 Charterhouse Buildings (constructed in 1968 for storing rolls of silk), in [[Clerkenwell]], [[London]], in July 1984.<ref>''Genealogists' Magazine'' March 1984, vol.21, no.5, p.163-164; June 1984, vol.21, no.6, notice inside front cover. {{ISSN|0016-6391}}</ref>
==Facilities== The Society possesses the largest family history research library in the United Kingdom, accessible to all members without charge and available to be used by the general public on payment of a fee. Society holdings include thousands of [[parish register]] and [[nonconformist register]] copies on microfilm or microfiche or in manuscript, typescript or published form, along with [[tombstone]] inscriptions, [[Will (law)|will]], [[marriage licence]] and [[census]] transcripts and indexes, trade and residential directories and [[poll book]]s (lists of voters), family histories, biographical dictionaries, works on [[apprentices]] and occupations, the armed forces, school and university registers and histories, genealogical journals and many other related works. The library catalogue is available on the Society's web site.
In 2000, the Society made a number of its genealogical datasets available online on the commercial service [[British Origins]], with some free access for Society members. This material is now hosted commercially by [[Findmypast]] with a separate free service to members run by the Society itself on its own web site using the [[Frontis Archive Publishing System]].
==Activities== [[File:Society of Genealogists.jpg|thumb|The current home of the Society of Genealogists in Charterhouse Buildings off Goswell Road, London]]The emphasis is on [[United Kingdom|British]], [[British Empire]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] sources, but the Society has some sources for most parts of the world.
The Society's Internet suite offers free access to major genealogical websites including Ancestry and Findmypast.
The society runs a programme of lectures, visits, and courses every year, and publishes textbooks, indexes, and a quarterly journal, ''Genealogists' Magazine''. The latter is currently edited by Michael Gandy.
==Prince Michael of Kent Award== The society's patron is [[Prince Michael of Kent]], after whom the Society has named a prestigious award (created in 2000), granted periodically to a person or organisation which has made an outstanding contribution to genealogy.
===Recipients=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; text-align: left; " |- !Year !Recipient |- |2000 |[[Family Records Centre]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Diary May, 2000|author=Prince Michael of Kent|url=http://www.princemichael.org.uk/diary/months/may_2000.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031119164329/http://www.princemichael.org.uk/diary/months/may_2000.html|archivedate=2003-11-19|df=}}</ref> |- |2004 |[[ABM Publishing Ltd]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Family Tree Magazine and Practical Family History|author=ABM Publishing Ltd|url=http://www.family-tree.co.uk/abm-publishing-about.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208150207/http://www.family-tree.co.uk/abm-publishing-about.html|archivedate=2008-02-08|df=}}</ref> |- |2006 |[[Genealogical Society of Utah]] <ref>{{cite web|title=AGM minutes 2006|author=Society of Genealogists|url=http://www.sog.org.uk/governance/agm2006_minutes.pdf}}</ref> |- |2007 |[[FreeBMD]] <ref name=BMDPR/> |- |2011 |Alex Graham, CEO Wall to Wall <ref>{{cite web|title=Announcement|author=Society of Genealogists|url=http://www.societyofgenealogists.com/the-society-of-genealogists-prince-michael-of-kent-award-2011-is-given-to-alex-graham-ceo-of-tv-production-company-wall-to-wall/}}</ref> |}
Years not listed means no one was awarded.<ref name=BMDPR>{{cite web|title=Society of Genealogists makes prestige award to FreeBMD|author=Society of Genealogists|url=http://www.sog.org.uk/files/pr-20070628_award.pdf}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''''South Australian Vigneron and Gardeners' Manual''''' (July 1843) was the first gardening book published (and one of the first books locally written and published) in the newly founded colony of [[South Australia]].
It was written by [[George McEwin]] (1815 – 1885), then gardener to vigneron [[George Stevenson (editor)|George Stevenson]], published by [[James Allen (Australian colonial author)|James Allen]], and sold by subscription at 3s. then retailed at 4s.<ref name=advt>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27444860 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=24 June 1843 |accessdate=18 November 2011 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Subscribers== The list of subscribers reads like a "Who's Who" of SA colonists. At 24 June 1843 they were: :His Excellency the Governor (10 copies) :His Honour the Judge (2) :James Allen, North Adelaide (6) :Capt. Allen, Port Gawler :George Alston, Sturt River :[[G. A. Anstey]] (2) :David Ball, Vine Farm, Prospect :John Beerjew, North Adelaide :Charles Berkeley, Cranford :William Blyth, Hindley Street :C. F. Bonner :J. Bouch, Hindley Street (2) :John Bradford, Sturt River :Alex. Brodie, Claremont Cottage :Lewis Bryant (2) :[[W. H. Burford]], Grenfell Street :T. Burr :John Calder, Port Adelaide :G. L. Cooper, Hindmarsh :J. Cousins, Brighton :James Coutts :K. J. F. Crawford :J. D. Finnis, North Adelaide :C. Davies, M.D., North Adelaide (2) :Rev. R. Drummond, Brownhill Creek (6) :George Duke, South Terrace :J. S. Duncan, Reed-beds :E. N. Emmett, Lyndoch Valley (2) :[[C. G. Everard]], Ashford :S. Fairlie, Hindley Street :Charles Fenn, Kensington :Flett and Linklater, Hindley Street (2) :John Foreman, South Terrace :C. E. Fortnimin (3) :A. Foster :James Frew, Fullarton (2) :Lieut Frome (2:) :Samuel D. Gill :[[Osmond Gilles]], Glen Osmond :John Guthrie, Fairfield :R. L. Hall :Jean Harkness, Grahamshall :[[Alexander Hay (South Australian politician)|Alexander Hay]], Little Para :William Hay, North Adelaide :William Higginson, Kensington :H. D. Hilton, Grenfell Street :J. Humphrey, Islington :J. A. Jackson (2) :H. Johnson (3) :A. C. Kelly M.D., Morphett Vale :W. G. Lambert, Grenfell Street :H. W. Litchfield, Grenfell Street :W. Little, Mount Barker :H. Manfull, Challaston Grove :C. Mann, Syleham, on the Torrens (3) :R. Miller, Hindley Street :Capt. John Mitchell, Mount Barker (2) :T. J. Mitchell, North Adelaide :T. N. Mitchell, Mount Barker (2) :Capt. W. C. Mitchell, ship ''Frankfeld'' (2) :[[Jacob Montefiore]] :R. L. Montefiore :A. M. Mundy (3) :W. H. Newenham, North Terrace :Thomas Norris, North Adelaide :P. Peachey, Kermode Street :C. G. Platts, Hindley Street (6) :Edward Roberts, Pine Forest :John Roedan, Lyndoch Valley :Thomas Round, Weymouth Street :William Seargeant, Log House Farm :Matthew Smith, Gawler Place :Emanuel Spiller, Grenfell Street :[[George Stevenson (editor)|George Stevenson]], North Adelaide (6) :[[Samuel Stocks|Samuel Stocks, junr.]], Grenfell Street :[[Captain Sturt]] (2) :David Sutherland, Sturt River :John Taylor, Bank of South Australia :W. K. Thomas, Kermode Street :Edmund Trimmer, North Adelaide :John and James Turner :M. Turton, Rundle Street :J. Walker, Havering, on the Torrens (2) :John Warden, North Adelaide :J. Wetherspoon, Franklin Street :Nathanial Wheaten, Park Farm :Frederic Wicksteed, Adelaide :John T. Wicksteed, Taranake, New Zealand :Thomas Williams, Hermitage :E. Wright, junr., North Terrace :George Young, Port Adelaide<ref name=advt/>
The Public Library of South Australia produced a [[facsimile]] edition in 1962.<ref>http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/2162767</ref>

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use American English|date=August 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = The BLT Cookbook | title_orig = | translator = | image = The BLT Cookbook.jpg | caption = Book cover | author = Michele Anna Jordan | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Cooking]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = [[William Morrow and Company|William Morrow Cookbooks]] | pub_date = June 3, 2003 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 160 | isbn = 0-06-008773-0 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The BLT Cookbook''''' is a [[cookbook]] about the preparation of [[BLT|bacon, lettuce, and tomato]] (BLT) sandwiches. It was written by Michele Anna Jordan and was published by [[William Morrow and Company|William Morrow Cookbooks]] in the United States in June 2003. Jordan is a food writer and has written for ''[[The Press Democrat]]''; ''The BLT Cookbook'' is her 14th published book. She researched the book for ten years and in the process she taste-tested hundreds of variations on the sandwich, describing it as America's most beloved sandwich. She instructs the reader on how to acquire and prepare the best ingredients for the sandwich. The book includes recipes with varying ingredients, though each recipe includes tomatoes. Many recipes in the book are not sandwiches, and include appetizers, soups, salads, and desserts. Jordan also suggests wines to accompany the sandwich.
The book was positively received, and the [[National Pork Board]] highly recommended it.<ref name="lawson" /> A review in ''[[The Detroit News]]'' said that the book includes "mouthwatering recipes",<ref name="lawson" /> and the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' called it a "neat little book" on the subject.<ref name="saekel" /> The food editor for the ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]'' wrote that the book's recipes "will surely shake up your next toasted meal".<ref name="pankey" /> The ''[[Anchorage Daily News]]'' called it the "definitive book" on the BLT sandwich.<ref name="mitchell" />
==Content summary== ''The BLT Cookbook'' discusses the author's love of the BLT sandwich,<ref name="peyton" /> which according to Jordan is "America's favorite sandwich".<ref name="okun">{{cite news| last = Okun | first = Janice| title =Gourmandise | work = [[The Buffalo News]] | page = E2 | date = June 8, 2003 }}</ref> The author wrote, "There are times when the BLT just tastes right, primal and true, the best thing you could ever eat. The play of the salt and acid, the silk of the tomato against the salt crunch of the bacon ... It is sheer delight."<ref name="thym" /> She discusses ways the combination can be used in soups, appetizers, and salads.<ref name="peyton" /><ref name="okun" /> Recipes are provided for multiple versions of the BLT sandwich.<ref name="peyton" /> Jordan writes that to make the best sandwich, one should select the finest ingredients.<ref name="classic">{{cite news| last =Milwaukee Journal Sentinel staff | title = Classic BLT sensational summer fare | work = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] | location =[[Wisconsin]] | publisher = Journal Sentinel Inc. | page = 04 | date = July 20, 2003 }}</ref> She recommends shopping at farmers' markets for fresh tomatoes, a butcher for choice bacon, and a bakery for fresh bread.<ref name="classic" /> The author recommends mayonnaise brands [[Hellmann's]] and [[Best Foods]],<ref name="classic" /> and Niman bacon from California.<ref>{{cite news| last = Schamberg | first =Anne | title =Bring on the bacon — Those sizzlin' strips of bacon are back in a big way| work = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] | location =[[Wisconsin]] | publisher = Journal Sentinel Inc. | page = 01 | date = July 20, 2003 }}</ref> Jordan writes, "For lettuce, remove the first outer leaf and then use only the next three layers. Further in, iceberg lettuce gets a little cabbagey."<ref>{{cite news| last =Heller | first = Ann | coauthors = | title =Tasty BLT — It's all in the order of placement| work =[[Dayton Daily News]] | location = [[Ohio]] | publisher = Cox Ohio Publishing| page = E4 | date = July 30, 2003}}</ref>
''The BLT Cookbook'' begins with a recipe for a mini-cocktail selection of the BLT, followed by a larger version that the author recommends for large gatherings such as picnics.<ref name="saekel" /> Non-traditional presentations of the BLT combination include "Tomatoes Stuffed with Bacon Risotto", "Potato Soup with Tomatoes and Bacon" and "Tomato Bread Pudding".<ref name="okun" /> The author presents varieties of the BLT that omit one ingredient.<ref name="okun" /> "The Fisherman's BLT"{{mdash}}which uses seafood{{mdash}}is an alternative to the standard sandwich and the "ZLT" comprises zucchini, lettuce and tomato.<ref name="enna">{{cite news| last = Enna| first = Renee | title = BLTs – and the red diva| work =[[Chicago Tribune]] | language = | publisher = | page = 6| date = July 2, 2003 }}</ref> Jordan was inspired by a salmon sandwich she bought at Pike Place Market in Seattle to create a BLT sandwich with salmon.<ref>{{cite news| last = Peterson| first = Diane | title = Tomato tribune — Wine country chefs pay homage to a vegetable once misunderstood, now a worldwide staple | work = [[The Press Democrat]]| location = [[Santa Rosa, California]] | page = D1 | date =August 27, 2003}}</ref> The "Bacon, Leek and Tomato Strudel" is a dish that does not use bread.<ref name="okun" /> All recipes presented in ''The BLT Cookbook'' include tomatoes.<ref name="okun" /> Towards the end of the book, recipes for bread pudding, strudel and tomato pie are included.<ref name="saekel" /> Selected wines that Jordan recommends to accompany her dishes include a Rhone-style red, [[beaujolais]], or [[pinot noir]].<ref name="pankey" />
==Background== Food writer Michele Anna Jordan has contributed columns published in the food and wine section of ''[[The Press Democrat]]''.<ref name="peyton" /> and restaurant reviews for the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''.<ref name="saekel">{{cite news| last = Saekel | first = Karola | title =What's new — Cook's books — Don't hold the mayo | work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | publisher = The Chronicle Publishing Co. | page = E2 | date = July 16, 2003 }}</ref> ''The BLT Cookbook'' is Jordan's 14th book.<ref name="peyton">{{cite news| last = Peyton | first =Sara | title =Rafting and writing: Poet presents a unique workshop | work =[[The Press Democrat]] | location =[[Santa Rosa, California]] | page = G5 | date = June 8, 2003 }}</ref> She decided to write about the BLT sandwich after discovering it was a good remedy for [[morning sickness]],<ref name="post">{{cite news| last =The Cincinnati Post staff | title = Post scripts — Tomato source | work = [[The Cincinnati Post]]| location =[[Ohio]] | page =B1 | date = August 6, 2003 }}</ref> and that others who frequented a food website shared her love of the BLT.<ref name="post" /> Jordan spent ten years researching for the book, and spent a winter writing it.<ref name="thym" /> During her research, Jordan taste-tested hundreds of variations on the BLT sandwich.<ref name="thym" /> In 2003 the author hosted two radio programs on [[KRCB-FM]], "Mouthful with Michele Anna Jordan" and "Red Shoes Rodeo".<ref name="newmouthful">{{cite news| last = The Press Democrat staff | title = | work =[[The Press Democrat]] | location = [[Santa Rosa, California]] | page = D10 | date =October 1, 2003 }}{{incomplete citation|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Jordan | first = Michele Anna | title = Plums, apples, veggies abound at Gualala Farmers Market | work = [[The Press Democrat]] | location = [[Santa Rosa, California]]| page = D1 | date = September 24, 2003 }}</ref> The year the book was published, Jordan crafted a {{convert|1248|sqft|m2|adj=on}} BLT sandwich at the Kendall-Jackson Tomato Festival.<ref>{{cite news| last =Smith | first = Chris | title =There's a beef over that 146-foot BLT | work = [[The Press Democrat]]| location = [[Santa Rosa, California]] | page = B1 | date = September 9, 2008 }}</ref>
==Reception== ''The BLT Cookbook'' is "highly recommended" by the [[National Pork Board]].<ref name="lawson" /> Kate Lawson of ''[[The Detroit News]]'' wrote that the book offers "mouthwatering recipes ranging from variations on the classic sandwich to soups, salads and pastas."<ref name="lawson">{{cite news| last =Lawson | first = Kate | title = Bacon's back in favor — Low-carb diets, adventurous cooks have more people living high on the hog | work = [[The Detroit News]] | location =[[Michigan]] | page = 12D| date =July 10, 2003 }}</ref> Karola Saekel of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote, "Recipes for recommended basics like aioli and tomato concasse round out the neat little book."<ref name="saekel" /> Food editor of the ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]'' Deborah Pankey wrote in her review of the book, "While giving the titled trio its due respect, author Michele Anna Jordan introduces a host of other ingredients that will surely shake up your next toasted meal (yes, she favors toast to help maintain the sandwich's structure.)"<ref name="pankey">{{cite news| last = Pankey | first = Deborah | title = Jazzing the BLT up into more than a simple sandwich | work = [[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] | location =[[Arlington Heights, Illinois]] | page = 4, Section: Food | date = July 16, 2003 }}</ref>
''[[The Cincinnati Post]]'' said, "[Jordan's] book presents practically all the possibilities for BLT combinations as she leaves the two slices of white toast far behind".<ref name="post" /> Staff writer for ''[[ANG Newspapers]]'' Jolene Thym wrote, "Not simply a cookbook, the little handbook is a discourse on the sandwich that is elegant enough to coax even the most virtuous eaters to gobble pork fat and mayonnaise with abandon."<ref name="thym">{{cite news| last = Thym ([[ANG Newspapers]])| first = Jolene | title =Love letter to the BLT | work = [[Tri-Valley Herald]] | location = [[Pleasanton, California]] | publisher = Media NewsGroup, Inc. | page = Section: Bay Area Living | date = September 10, 2003 }}</ref> T.C. Mitchell of the ''[[Anchorage Daily News]]'' said ''The BLT Cookbook'' is the "definitive book" on the sandwich.<ref name="mitchell">{{cite news| last =Mitchell | first = T.C. | title = Rasher Classic — Chief ingredient for a BLT is hard to get in Alaska| work =[[Anchorage Daily News]] | location = [[Alaska]] | page = D1 | date = June 16, 2004 }}</ref>
==See also==

[[File:Video Databank Logo.jpg|thumb|The logo from the School of the Art Institute's Video Data Bank]] '''Video Data Bank (VDB)''' is an international [[video art]] distribution organization and resource in the United States for videos by and about contemporary artists. Located in Chicago, Illinois, VDB was founded at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]] in 1976 at the inception of the media arts movement.
VDB provides experimental video art, documentaries made by artists, and interviews with visual artists and critics for a wide range of audiences. These include [[Microcinema|microcinemas,]] moving image festivals, media arts centers, universities, libraries, museums, community-based workshops, public television, and [[cable TV]] [[Public-access television]] centers. Video Data Bank currently holds over 6,000 titles in distribution, by more than 600 artists, available in a variety of screening and archival video formats. It also actively publishes anthologies and curated programs of video art.
The preservation of historic video is an ongoing project of the Video Data Bank. The total holdings, including works both in and out of distribution, include over 10,000 titles of original and in some cases, rarely seen, video art and documentaries from the late 1960s on. The VDB functions as a Department of the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] and is supported in part by awards from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] and the [[Illinois Arts Council]].
== History ==
In 1974, VDB co-founders [[Kate Horsfield]] and [[Lyn Blumenthal]], graduate students at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, began conducting video interviews with women artists who they felt were underrepresented critically in the art world. After buying a Panasonic [[Portapak]] and successfully conducting talks with painters [[Joan Mitchell]] and [[Agnes Martin]] and curator [[Marcia Tucker]], the pair decided to continue the series. "It was really a kind of accident,” noted Horsfield in a 2007 interview. “We were looking for inspiration for ourselves, but we were also looking for information on what was happening. If you read art magazines in the early '70s, it was very rare to see any real coverage of any women artists." <ref>http://www.villagevoice.com/film/before-youtube-6426166</ref> In 1976 Horsfield and Blumenthal officially founded the Video Data Bank, taking over a small collection of student video productions and interviews that was begun by [[Phil Morton]] at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. They went on to add to the archive, conducting talks with prominent artists of the period such as [[Alice Neel]], [[Lucy Lippard]], [[Lee Krasner]], [[Barbara Kruger]], and the [[Guerrilla Girls]], who appeared wearing their trademark gorilla masks.
Lyn Blumenthal died in 1988, and the VDB maintains the Lyn Blumenthal Memorial Scholarship. Horsfield remained director of the collection until her retirement in 2006, when she was succeeded by Abina Manning. In 2007 the National Alliance for Media Arts and Culture (NAMAC) presented Video Data Bank with its Outstanding Media Arts Organization Award.
== Collection ==
The Video Data Bank collection includes video produced from 1968 to the present. The early video art represented includes many titles from the Castelli-Sonnabend collection, the first and most prominent collection of video art assembled in the United States, produced between 1968 and 1980. These works represent examples of the first experiments in video art and include conceptual and feminist performances recorded on video, experiments with the video signal, and 'guerilla' documentaries representing a counter-cultural view of the historical events of the 1960s. Artists included are [[Vito Acconci]], [[Lynda Benglis]], [[Dara Birnbaum]], [[Joan Jonas]], [[Bruce Nauman]] and [[William Wegman (photographer)|William Wegman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vdb.org/titles/surveying-first-decade-volume-2|title=Surveying the First Decade: Volume 2|work=vdb.org}}</ref>
The collection includes the work of contemporary artists who largely address post-modern themes such as feminism, AIDS, gender studies, guerilla television, technology, and identity, among them [[Sadie Benning]], [[Jem Cohen]], [[Harun Farocki]], [[Walid Raad]], Paul Chan, [[Guillermo Gómez-Peña]], [[Miranda July]], and [[George Kuchar]].
The On Art and Artists collection includes interviews with visual artists, photographers and critics. The interviews focus on the development of the artists' body of work.
In addition, Video Data Bank represents two important video archives: the Kuchar Archive, encompassing the extensive video output of twin brothers George and Mike Kuchar, and the Videofreex Archive, which chronicles the counter-cultural movement of the 1960s and 1970s as documented by the 10-person collective.
== ''Surveying the First Decade'' == ''Surveying the First Decade: Video Art and Alternative Media in the U.S.'' is a 17-hour compilation of experimental and independent video created from 1968-1980, the first decade of video art production produced in 1995. The anthology includes 68 titles by more than 60 artists, and is curated into eight programs ranging from conceptual, performance-based, feminist, and image-processed works, to documentary and grassroots activism.
Chris Hill, former video curator at [[Hallwalls|Hallwalls Contemporary Arts Center]] in Buffalo, New York, curated the project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vdb.org/titles/surveying-first-decade-volume-1|title=Surveying the First Decade: Volume 1|work=vdb.org}}</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist|2}}
== References == *Halter, Ed (2007). "Before YouTube," ''Village Voice'', http://www.villagevoice.com/film/before-youtube-6426166.{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Tamblyn, Christine (1991). "Image Processing in Chicago Video Art," ''Leonardo,'' Vol. 24, No. 3, pp. 303–310 * {{cite book |editor-last = Horsfield |editor-first = Kate |editor2=Lucas Hilderbrand | year = 2006 | title = Feedback: The Video Data Bank Catalog of Video Art and Artist Interviews | publisher = Temple University Press | location = Philadelphia, PA | isbn = 1-59213-182-4 }} * {{cite book | last = Juhasz | first = Alexandra | authorlink = | year = 2001 | title = Women of Vision: Histories in Feminist Film and Video | publisher = University of Minnesota Press | location = | isbn = 0-8166-3372-X }} * Horsfield, Kate. "Towards a History of Chicago Video." In Art in Chicago 1945-1995, 128. Chicago: Museum of Contemporary Art, 1996.
== External links == *[http://www.vdb.org Video Data Bank] *[http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/films/535 Feedback: The Video Data Bank, Video Art, and Artist Interviews—Reprised, (Film Exhibition May 17–31, 2007)]
[[Category:Arts organizations based in Illinois]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:Art Institute of Chicago]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} '''Walter Drowley Filmer''' (1 September 1865 – 24 August 1944) was an early pioneer of [[X-rays]] in Australia, a wireless engineer, for a time ran the [[British Royal Train]], and a world class entomologist that discovered several new species in his homeland. Filmer was a naturalist and established a private collection at his residence that thousands of people visited.
==Life and Times== In 1865, Filmer was born in [[Maitland, New South Wales]], Australia. He was the son of William Filmer (1828-1902) and Amy Filmer née Hatton (1831-1901).<ref>Australia Births and Baptisms, 1792-1981. Database. FamilySearch. Filmer. Citing Maitland, Australia; FHL microfilm 991,451.</ref> He married Mary Anne E. née Chessell (1868-1951) in 1890 in [[Sydney]]. The couple had 4 children: son, Walter Harold Alexandra Filmer (1892-1964), born on 10 February 1892 in Sydney; daughter, Mary Filmer (1895-1895), born in 1895 in [[Petersham, New South Wales|Petersham]]; son, Leroy Drowley Filmer (1902-1976), born on 5 April 1902 in [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]]; and son, Eric Filmer (1903-1986), born 10 December 1903 in [[Toronto, New South Wales|Toronto]].<ref>Editor (16 February 2011). Walter Drowley Filmer. Family Tree Web. Genealogy. Australia.</ref> In 1944, he died at home at [[Lake Macquarie]].<ref name=Owen>Owen, M. (February 1965). WALTER DROWLEY FILMER, 1865-1944: AUSTRALIAN X-RAY PIONEER. ''Journal of the College of Radiologists of Australasia''. 9: 10-23.</ref><ref>Australia Deaths and Burials, 1816-1980. Database. FamilySearch. Walter Drowley Filmer, 1944. Citing reference 303; FHL microfilm 991,451.</ref>
In 1876, at the age of 11, he was apprenticed to a boot maker. In 1884, by the age of 19, Filmer became an assistant telegraph line repairer and operator with the New South Wales Post Office. From 1885 to 1912, he was appointed to the [[New South Wales Government Railways]] as [[Telegraphy|telegraph officer]]. In 1890, Filmer was selected to go to England as a cadet to study railway electrical science and safety. In England he lived with an uncle at the [[Tower of London]]. At one point he found himself in charge of the [[British Royal Train]] that ran from [[London]] to [[Edinburgh]]. After completion of railway studies in England in 1891, Filmer returned to New South Wales. With newly acquired knowledge and skills, he received appointment as Electrical Inspector for Railways and remained in that capacity until retirement in 1908.<ref name=Owen/><ref>Filmer, Walter Drowley. (1897). Letterbook, 1890-1897. Electricity and Railways. Railroads, New South Wales, Electrification. Reports to the Commissioners for Railways, Sydney. Australia.</ref><ref name=Home>Home, R.W. & Needham, P.J. (June 1995). Walter Drowley Filmer. Physics in Australia to 1945. Australian Science Archives Project.</ref><ref name=Trove>Editor. (2009). Filmer, Walter Drowley (1865-1944). Trove. National Library of Australia.</ref><ref name=Hartley>Hartley, Dulcie. (2002). Walter Drowley Filmer 1865 - 1944: Physicist, geologist, botanist, biologist & zoologist. Fennell Bay, NSW. Australia.</ref>
In 1909, Filmer was appointed head [[Teacher|instructor]] of [[electricity]] for [[Mining|mines]] at [[Hunter Institute of TAFE|Newcastle Technical College]], [[Hunter Institute of TAFE|Maitland Technical College]] and [[Hunter Institute of TAFE|Cessnock Technical College]] and taught Applied Electricity. These schools were all mining technical colleges. From 1909 to 1931, he was physics master at Newcastle Technical College, and retired in 1931.<ref name=Owen/><ref>Filmer, W.D. (1920). Notes on the physiography of Lake Macquarie. Read before the Newcastle Division, Institution of Engineers, Australia on 22 May 1920. Newcastle Division of the Australian Institution of Engineers. Newcastle, N.S.W. Australia.</ref><ref name=Trove/><ref name=Hartley/>
==Professional Service== *[[Institution of Electrical Engineers|Institute of Electrical Engineers (London)]], member *[[Engineers Australia|Institute of Engineers (Australia)]], founding member *Maitland Scientific Society, member
==Wireless and X-Rays== Filmer received an appointment as [[Wireless telegraphy|wireless engineer]] to the [[Douglas Mawson]] [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition|Expedition]] to the [[South Pole]], but was unable to accept since the Railway Department would not grant him a release to participate. Filmer and his brother Bert Filmer operated one of the first [[X-ray]] installation in Australia, three days after cables were received in Australia that announced the discovery of X-rays. From 1896 to 1910, the Filmer brothers were appointed Honorary Electricians at [[Newcastle Hospital]] and were X-rays operators at Newcastle Hospital.<ref name=Owen/><ref name=Home/><ref name=Trove/><ref name=Hartley/>
==Entomologist== Filmer was interested in studies that involved [[entomology]] and [[marine life]]. He researched parasites, a noteworthy achievement was the discovery of a new [[Family (Biology)|family]]: ‘’[[Cestoda|Cestoda genera]]’’, that became known as ''Filmeric''. He had an extensive collection of insects, comprising several thousand samples, and perhaps one of the leading private collections at the time. Filmer developed a keen interest in field work that involved spiders and teamed with Dr. [[Jiří Baum]] of the [[National Museum (Prague)|Prague Museum]], the [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[zoologist]] and a leading world authority on [[spiders]].<ref name=Owen/><ref name=Trove/><ref name=Hartley/><ref>Baum, Jiří. (1938). On the habits of the Australian spider Dinopis subrufus L. Koch. Mem Soc Vestnik Ceskoslovenske Zoologicke Spolecnosti Prague. (5): 28-32.</ref> Filmer performed research with Dr. [[Robert John Tillyard|Robin Tillyard]] on [[fossil]] insects.<ref>Tillyard, Robin John. (1917). Mesozoic and tertiary Insects of Queensland. Plannipenia, Trichoptera and the new order Protomecoptera. In Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales. 42(1): 175-200.</ref><ref>Tillyard, R. J. (1926). Upper Permian insects of New South Wales.</ref><ref>Tillyard, Robin John. (1926). The Insects of Australia and New Zealand.</ref> He also teamed with John Mitchell, of Newcastle, on fossil [[trilobites]], and was honored with a species being named after him.<ref>Mitchell, John. (1918). The Carboniferous trilobites of Australia. In Proc. Linn. Soc. NSW. 43(3): 437-494.</ref><ref>Mitchell, J. (1919). On two new trilobites from Bowning. In Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales. (44): 441-449.</ref><ref>Mitchell, John. (1919). Some additional trilobites from New South Wales. Proceedings of the [[Linnean Society of New South Wales]]. 44: 850-6.</ref>
In 1930, Filmer collected 3 [[cestodes]] at [[Tuggerah]] from a fresh water [[tortoise]], ''[[Chelodina longicollis]]'', and submitted these to the [[South Australian Museum]] for identification. [[Thomas Harvey Johnston]] reported that this was the first known occurrence for an ''[[Amphilinidea|Amphilinid]]'' to be collected in the [[Southern Hemisphere]], and the only known instance of a member of the order in a [[reptile]], the other known species described, one example from [[sturgeons]] in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], two from a primitive fresh-water fish from northern [[South America]], and one from a marine fish off the coast of [[Ceylon]].<ref>Johnston, T. Harvey. (1931). An amphilinid cestode from an Australian tortoise. Austral. J. Exp. Biol. Med. Sc. Adelaide. 8: 1-7.</ref><ref>Johnston, T. Harvey. (1934). Remarks on some Australian Cestodaria. Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales. 59(1-2): 66-70.</ref>
==Accolades== As previously mentioned, Filmer is credited in the [[animalia]] and [[insecta]] world with species named in his honor for significant contributions.
Australia is one of the few countries to recognize a group of people for a major achievement where the group happened to work independently in different locations in Australia. These significant achievements by 3 individuals are disputed even to this day. Not the historical fact that the events occurred, but the claim of who accomplished what first, and who should receive credit for being the first in Australia to perform [[medical radiography]]. [[Australia Post]] decided a fair way was to depict all three individuals on a [[postage stamp]], issued to coincided and commemorate the 100th anniversary of [[Wilhelm Röntgen]]’s discovery of [[X-rays]]. On 7 September 1995, Father [[Joseph Patrick Slattery]], [[Thomas Ranken Lyle|Thomas Lyle]], and Walter Drowley Filmer were recognized as the pioneers of X-ray technology in Australia.<ref name=Smith>Smith, Tony. (2009). A short history of the origins of radiography in Australia. ''Radiography''. 15: E42-E47.</ref><ref>Johnston, T.P. (November 2015). Physicians and Radiologists and Other Contributors to the Health Sciences. A Philatelic Look at Health Physics History. ''Health Physics News''. 43(11): 24-25.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Subject bar | portal1=Australia | portal2=Medicine | portal3=History of science | portal4=Entomology | portal5=Biography }}

{{Other uses}} {{Redirect|Wishes}} {{original research|date=September 2008}} [[File:I samma ögonblick var hon förvandlad till en underskön liten älva.jpg|thumb|A [[fairy]] offering wishes, illustration by [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]] to Alfred Smedberg's ''The seven wishes'']]
A '''wish''' is a [[hope]] or [[desire]] for something. Fictionally, wishes can be used as [[plot device]]s. In folklore, opportunities for "making a wish" or for wishes to "come true" or "be granted" are themes that are sometimes used.
==In fiction==
In [[fiction]] a wish is a [[supernatural]] demand placed on the recipient's unlimited request. When it is the center of a tale, the wish is usually a template for a [[morality tale]], "be careful what you wish for"; it can also be a small part of a tale, in which case it is often used as a [[plot device]]. One can wish on many things for example: wishing wells, dandelions when one blows the seeds or light them on fire, stars and much more. When one wishes in a well he or she throws money in, in the hope his or her wish comes true, the money normally goes to a charity.
A template for fictional wishes could be ''[[The Book of One Thousand and One Nights]]'', specifically the tale of [[Aladdin]], although in the tale of Aladdin the actual wishes were only part of the tale. Also, Aladdin's demands, while outrageous, were mainly variations on wealth (which is still often taken as the most common request).
Classically the wish provider is often a spirit, [[genie]], or similar entity, which is bound or constrained within a commonplace object (Aladdin's [[oil lamp]] for example) or a container closed with [[Solomon]]'s seal. Releasing the entity from its constraint, usually by some simple action, allows the object's possessor to make a wish.
The subservience of the extraordinarily powerful entity to the wisher can be explained in several ways. The entity may be grateful to be free of its constraint and the wish is a thank-you gift. The entity may be bound to obedience by its prison or some other item that the wisher possesses. The entity may, by its nature, be unable to exercise its powers without an initiator.
Other wish providers are a wide variety of, more or less, inanimate objects. W.W. Jacob's [[The Monkey's Paw|Monkey's Paw]] is an example of this. [[Piers Anthony]] puts a spin on this idea in ''[[Castle Roogna]]'': a magic ring claims to grant wishes and then claims credit when a wish comes true, apparently from the unaided efforts of the characters—but every wish made on the ring sooner or later comes true.<ref>John Grant and John Clute, ''The Encyclopedia of Fantasy'', "Rings", p. 813 {{ISBN|0-312-19869-8}}</ref>
Some wishes appear to be granted by nothing in particular. [[Snow White]]'s mother's wish for a beautiful child might have been a coincidence,<ref>Maria Tatar, ''The Annotated Brothers Grimm'', p. 243 W. W. Norton & company, London, New York, 2004 {{ISBN|0-393-05848-4}}</ref> but the father's wish in "[[The Seven Ravens]]" [[Shapeshifting#Ill-advised wishes|transforms]] his seven sons into ravens,<ref>Maria Tatar, ''The Annotated Brothers Grimm'', p. 136 W. W. Norton & company, London, New York, 2004 {{ISBN|0-393-05848-4}}</ref> just as the mother's wish in "[[The Raven (Brothers Grimm)|The Raven]]" transforms her daughter. This is common in a tale involving a person, male or female, wishing for a child, even one that is [[Hans My Hedgehog|a hedgehog]], or [[The Myrtle|a sprig of myrtle]], or no bigger than [[The Hazel-nut Child|a hazel nut]].
The number of wishes granted varies. Aladdin had an unlimited number in the original story, but was restricted to three wishes in the [[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|1992 Disney film]]. As in the [[Charles Perrault]] tale "[[The Ridiculous Wishes]]", three is the most common,<ref>Maria Tatar, ''The Annotated Brothers Grimm'', p. 166 W. W. Norton & company, London, New York, 2004 {{ISBN|0-393-05848-4}}</ref> but others may be granted to fit the constraints of the tale. Several authors have spun variations of the wish for more wishes theme, though some disallow this as cheating.
In many stories the ''wording'' of the wish is extremely important. For example, characters often say, "I wish I was wealthy." This wording could be taken literally, the wish granted so that at one time the wisher was (used to be) wealthy but is not any more. Saying, "I wish to be wealthy", then because "to be" refers to either the present or the future, they would become wealthy.
A common problem is the granter of the wish being either [[quibble (plot device)|extremely literal]] or through malice granting the request in a manner designed to cause maximum distress (such as a request for wealth being granted through inheritance/insurance on the death of a loved one). Certain authors have also tried an "always on" approach: the careless use of the word "wish" in everyday conversation having, often unpleasant, consequences.
==In practice== Some cultures have customs in which people are encouraged to "make a wish", such as blowing out the candles on a [[birthday cake]], seeing a [[meteoroid|shooting star]] at night, tossing a coin into a [[wishing well]] or [[fountain]] or breaking the [[Furcula|wishbone]] of a cooked [[turkey (bird)|turkey]]. Many believe such wishes can only come true if they are kept a secret from other people. Others, on the other hand, believe that wishes come true only if they are told to someone else.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}
==See also== {{wikiquote|Wishes}} {{wiktionary}} * [[Children's Wish Foundation]] * [[Kids wish network]] * [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]] * [[Three wishes joke]] * [[Wishful thinking]] * ''[[William's Wish Wellingtons]]''
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Superstitions]] [[Category:Recurrent elements in fairy tales]]
